ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki can't be loaded
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone, I am a research assistant for a professor and I run my prof's Moodle, which he uses for one of his classes. Both of us think this application is awesome - it's very versatile and based on feedback from his students, many of his students think the same. We do, however, have a recurring problem with the wiki part of the Moodle. Students are required to add content to an overall course wiki, which helps students collaborate and brainstorm with each other and serves as a good central point for study material for the entire course. This is the second semester that we are using the Moodle for a class, and in both semesters once we reach the end of the semester the wiki fails to load. What I mean by fails to load is that the wiki does not load and it seems like the user session "dies" - once you click on the wiki link the browser will sit there loading forever. You cannot reload the Moodle in the same browser/same computer, you have to go to a different computer and login (either as that same user or a different one) to load the Moodle up again. I've noticed that after about 20 minutes, you can reload the Moodle page from a 'crashed' session, so I believe it has something to do with user sessions. Furthermore, by the end of the semester, the wiki gets pretty damn big - maybe it has something to do with this size? We were thinking of setting up two wikis for next term: one containing information for the first half of the course, and the other for the second half of the course. We are using Moodle 1.7.1 (I think). I'm not at my web server right now so I cannot give more details right this moment, but if anyone is willing to help I will gladly dig up logs and do anything else. I am running the Moodle off of a Power Mac G5 (that's our web server) running Apache , PHP and MySQL . One more thing. I went digging through the My SQL console and I see that the wiki content is all there (and there's a lot of it!). I know I can dump the contents of the wiki SQL tables out - is there a way I can use this to re-create the wiki? I just want the students to have access to the information they contributed, as the final exam is coming up and it would be good study material for them. Thanks a lot to anyone who can offer insight and help, Fil

ResponsesInList.Title: Besides view, edit, links, and history, why not a disscusion?
ResponsesInList.Text: Besides view, edit, links, and history, have you think about including a disscusion page? (for example see mediawiki at wikipedia) Actually, every page of my class wiki points to a disscusion page. Nevertheless, this disscusion page is the same to the whole wiki, so you have to identify the theme of disscusion, the page, etc. If a disscusion command is included then every wiki page should have its own disscusion page. Best wishes, Juan Miguel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Besides view, edit, links, and history, why not a disscusion?
ResponsesInList.Text: In a wiki you are free to put your comments on the page under construction. (and others are free to read it, change it or throw it away. (It will still survive in the  history of that page.) It is another kind of collaboration: constructing together, very democratic, must be a horor for..

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Besides view, edit, links, and history, why not a disscusion?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ger: Think about several long discussions about several points in one page. The problem here is page contents mixing up with content discussions. One discussion page (with its own history) for each wiki page should be very helpful in achieving understable communication purposes. Best wishes, Juan Miguel

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki in Moodle 2.0 Development plans .... and call for contributions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, this week we have started to develope the Wiki for Moodle 2.0. Which is basically NWiki (same features, look and feel, etc) rewriten from scratch ( so the code will be neat and tiddy ). And we need some help to make this rigth, so we never need "to do another wiki ever". Help Wanted: - code revision: By the end of this week we will have the first functional release, just a wiki skeleton with a dumb parser, but with the full database and basic operations implemented. I beliebe that security issues need to be addressed here before we start building features. - markup and page behaviour - There will be a team working sole on the parsers (ewiki for backward compatibility, HTML(whateever editor) wiki, and Mediawikilike markup, and a new VerySimpleWikiFormat. We will use Unit tests to guide de parser development and be sure the things work as they are suposed to. We need you to send (as reply to this post for instance) wikipages with the page content (wiki format) and how is it suposed to be viewed ( XHTML ). If you want your wikis to render rigth in Wiki 2.0 : here's your chance. Thanks in advance for all your help. Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Do not use quotes in ewiki names !
ResponsesInList.Text:
E.g. if you create a wiki named like this: 
```text
wiki "suivi scolaire"
```
 You will get: Bad HTML like: 
```text
 a
 href
=
"view.php?id=3770&page=edit/wiki "
suivi 
scolaire"" 
title
=
"Modifier"
>
.....
```
 What's worse: The wiki entry page will show the first version created, but not the most recent version and you will have to go through history to find the page you just edited. ... just spent 30 minutes on this. Of course may can ask why people want to put quotes in names. It's beyond me but a typical thing that people who trust computers might do ;) PS: This is for the standard ewiki module. Moodle 1.9 + (Build: 20080326)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Do not use quotes in ewiki names !
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank-you! You just saved me 30 minutes of searching. (Why people want to put quotes in names -- my user created the wiki for her students to discuss a written story. She gave the wiki the name of the story in quotes. It seemed reasonable at the time...)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Do not use quotes in ewiki names !
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Daniel,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Do not use quotes in ewiki names !
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello again, I have just checked that after upgrade I have to rewrite course_id to mdl_wiki_entries in order to show the contents in a wiki with no "strange" characters in its name. I mean: we have a lot of wikis not showing contents after upgrade and it has nothing to do with previous misuse of the editor. Somebody with the same problem? Bye

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Do not use quotes in ewiki names !

ResponsesInList.Title: problem with characters above unicode v.2
ResponsesInList.Text:
hello,

when i try to write characters that are part of any version between 3.0 and 5.0 into the editor, they will not be displayed. even worse, all text that follows gets cut at the first problematic char.

this even applies to this editor i am using to write my message. take, for example, the chinese character nie4, http://www.unicode.org/cgi-bin/GetUnihanData.pl?codepoint=2414A . it is part of the unicode block "cjk unified ideographs extension b" which was introduced in version 3.1 of the unicode standard.

the character is part of the "founder extended" fonts for chinese, i.e. "mingliu-extb" or "simsun (founder extended)". it can be typed into any document using the normal windows ime (above win2k). it can also be typed (or copied from word) into the moodle editor and - while still in edit mode - is displayed correctly.

however, once the page is saved, all text after this character (including this character) will be cut off.

now, if you switch the editor to html-mode and enter the decimal ncr of that character (in this case it is 𤅊), THIS will be saved and displayed correctly.

what is the reason for it?

i have attached a short chinese line with 8 characters in word format as an example, where the 4th character is the problem.

with kind regards,
matthias arnold

ResponsesInList.Title: Notifications of new wiki page/activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: I think it could be very useful for course members to be notified by email when a student (or anyone) creates a new wiki page.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notifications of new wiki page/activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: You can do this with Event Monitoring rules - https://docs.moodle.org/38/en/Event_monitoring

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notifications of new wiki page/activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks — I never noticed that option before!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notifications of new wiki page/activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: Event monitoring for wiki is really clunky. It is not unusual for users to post to the wiki, then revise several times (sometimes just to improve formatting). Event monitoring sends a separate email every time it is saved — but if I set the threshold higher, someone who makes a single post without revising at all would not hit the threshold. It should provide a way to consolidate multiple edits to the same page by the same user, to eliminate multiple non-significant reports. The report doesn't give the title of the page being edited, only a link. I don't see any way to have all participants notified of changes to wiki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Help
ResponsesInList.Text: How do you add a course?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Help
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Laura. First off - are you sure you are on the right Moodle? This is the main global Moodle site where you ask questions about how Moodle works (which you did) and where you can download Moodle to test or use for your establishment. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blocking certain users in NWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Create a new role with all the wiki permissions set to 'prohibit; and call it something like 'blocked wiki users'. Then go to 'update this wiki' and click on the tab that allows you to set roles for this module context (locally assigned roles in 1.9) and assign the that role to the users you want to block.

ResponsesInList.Title: Unable to see images uploaded by students
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a very strange problem. If a teacher uploads and inserts an image into wiki page, everything works as it should. The image is visible to all users, no matter which browser they use. A student can also upload /insert an image with no problem. But if she uses Internet Explorer (6, 7 or 8) to view the wiki page, the image (uploaded by her or other student) is not visible. If she uses Firefox , Chrome, Opera the image is visible. The Moodle in question runs on Windows server with IIS . Just as curiosity: on Linux/ Apache server everything works without problem. The CamelCase is disabled Does anyone have any idea?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Unable to see images uploaded by students
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, I guess I found a solution for this problem. In the case of using [internal://image.png] for linking image in Wiki the IIS server sends the reply to browser's image request with status 302 in the header. Since there is no Locaton field in the header IE doesn't display the image as it wants to redirect. Other browsers apparently ignore the status 302 since there is no Location field and the image (which they actually expect from the server) is in the body of the reply. In the same scenario Apache sends the reply with status 200. The setting to change, in order to get things working is enable cgi.nph and set it to 1: from php.ini ; if cgi.nph is enabled it will force cgi to always sent Status: 200 with ; every request. cgi.nph = 1 Additional information: nph stands for non parsing headers. In our particular situation it would allow CGI to print Status: 200 header, which is normally skipped as it is not needed in most situations. Source link. With cgi.nph = 0, no status header is output unless you invoke header(), and then only if your status code isn't 200. With cgi.nph = 1, a status header is always output, defaulting to 200 if header() is not invoked. Source link. Should I create a bug report for this or there is nothing to change in Moodle code?

ResponsesInList.Title: Create a Wiki with Groups (Step by Step Instructions)
ResponsesInList.Text: When I first started using Moodle years ago the forums were very helpful to me. Now that I consider myself somewhat skilled in some of the aspects of this powerful teaching tool, I like to share my knowledge whenever I can. If anyone is struggling (like I did) on how to create a wiki with groups, I hope this step by step tutorial helps. Create a Wiki with Groups (Subject: American War Battles) Create Groups 1. On the course page select “Groups” under “Administration”. 2. On the groups page click the “Create group” button. 3. Fill in the following info for this group: · Group name: civil · Group description: Civil War Group Project · Enrollment key: civil · Click the “Save changes” button. 4. On the group page, make sure the civil group is selected and click the “Add/remove users” button. 5. Add users to the civil group (move them from the right box to the left box by clicking the “Add” button). When finished, click the “Back to groups” button. 6. Repeat steps 2-5 to create three additional groups (vietnam, world1, world2). Make sure to make the appropriate changes to Group description, and Enrollment key. Note: Enrollment key is optional. 7. Return to course page. Create the Wiki Turn editing on. Click the drop-down menu for “Add an Activity”. Select “Wiki”. On the “Add a Wiki” page fill in the following: Name: American War Battles Summary: American War Battles Group Project Type: Groups Print Wiki name on every page: Yes (optional) HTML mode: HTML only Allow Binary Files: Yes Disable CamelCase linking: Yes Group Mode: Visible Groups Visible: Show Grade Category: Uncategorized Click the “Save and return to course” button. On the course page click on the Wiki link. This is where you need to stop for a moment and get yourself oriented. Most likely you are on the “Groups wiki for civil” page in the “American War Battles Wiki (since this was the first group you created). If so, you are ready to begin created your Civil War page Wiki. If you would prefer to start with another war, simply click the drop-down on the top-right of the page labeled “Other Wikis:” and choose the wiki group you want to start with. On the lower portion of the page you should see a bold header: Edit this page ‘American War Battles’. ( I chose to start with the civil group so I will begin editing for the Civil War). Type the following: [The Battle of Shiloh] [The Battle of Gettysburg] [The Battle of New Orleans] Click the “Save” button On the top-right of the page choose the world1 group from the drop-down menu. Repeat steps 7-8 but replace the battles with battles from World War I. On the top-right of the page choose the world2 group from the drop-down menu. Repeat steps 7-8 but replace the battles with battles from World War II. On the top-right of the page choose the vietnam group from the drop-down menu. Repeat steps 7-8 but replace the battles with battles from the Vietnam War. Now the Wiki is ready for students to work in! Student Access to Wiki Go to course page. Click on the “American War Battles” Wiki. Select your group from the top-right drop-down menu. Click the ? to the right of the battle you want to begin working on. Get to work! Note: Students will only be able to edit within their group. Because the Group Mode was set to “Visible Groups” by the teacher, students will be able to view every groups work but will only be able to edit their own.

If the instructor is indeed creating student wikis, then after he has created it he will see a listing of every student when he opens the wiki. If he edits the wiki in this view he changes only the instructors version of the wiki, not the students. On the other side of the coin, the student does not see the material the teacher added to the wiki unless the teacher edits that specific student's wiki. As far as I know there is no way for a teacher to make universal changes to all the wikis, which is one reason it is handy to learn how to set up multipage student wikis.

ResponsesInList.Title: Creating a wiki infrastructure
ResponsesInList.Text:
I teach history at a community college and just switched from
Blackboard to Moodle primarily because of the built in wiki
application. Part of the class is a collaborative assignment where
groups of 2 or 3 students will research their own project. They are
each going edit their own page, which everyone can see, but only that
group can edit. I also want to create a central page from which there
are links to all the group pages. My main question is should there just
be one wiki and many pages, or many wikis linked to eachother? I have
already grouped the students, but how do I assign a page or wiki to a
specific group? Thanks, GP

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a wiki infrastructure
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Gary.  I've done something similar except I kept each group's work private.  I don't think there's a way to assign pages to specific groups, so that's something to keep in mind and pushes you to many wikis, which you can assign to groups.  Here's my recommendation. Let's say you have 3 groups.  You can create a wiki, call it "project".  In the setup page choose "groups" type with "visible groups" mode.  By doing this, you're automatically making as many wikis as you have groups. When you save your setup, the HTML editor will open up so you can compose the main page.  If you look at the top left of the screen, you'll see that you are actually editing the home page for one specific group.  On the top right, there is a drop-down box labeled "choose other wikis" or something like that which allows you to create a main page for each of your groups, one by one.  Cutting and pasting works well if you want the main pages to be the same. Students will see only one link on their main course page - it will just say Project with a wiki icon.  When they click on it, it will open one group's wiki - I would hope the one they can write on, but I'm not sure about that because I've never done visible groups.  They should have a drop-down box that would allow them to navigate among the different wikis. One caution -  you want to make sure that you don't have duplicate page names.  For example, maybe you're thinking about setting up each group with a main page that links to pages called "overview" "outline" and "resources".  You need to individualize the page names to, say, "overview-1" for group 1, "overview-2" for group 2 and so on.  Otherwise, unexpected things happen when you try to navigate to your own  overview page - you could easily end up on some other group's.  Even with separate groups, duplicate page names were a problem for me, and I can only guess it would be worse with visible groups. Good luck with it.  I think wikis are a great collaboration tool.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a wiki infrastructure
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Russ, That helps, but I am not there yet. How do I link to other wikis from the central or homepage wiki. I was able to link to other pages within the main wiki, but students cannot edit that. I also can't seem to change page names of other wikis. What I want to end up with is a main wiki page that only I can edit which serves as an index of topics, each linking to another group wiki. Everyone can see everything but only edit their own. Thanks, Gary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a wiki infrastructure
ResponsesInList.Text:
Gary, I think you're going to have difficulty setting up the scheme you
have in mind if I understand it correctly.  Every wiki in your
moodle has a link displayed on the main course page.  You could
set up a page (not a wiki per se, but just a topic summary) that names
the various wikis for the different groups and they will link
automatically, but I don't think you can force students to access the
wikis this way because each wiki will still have its own link on the
main page.  The duplication quickly gets confusing, and is
unnecessary because the drop down menu I mentioned allows students to
access all the other groups' wikis anyway.  In other words, the
model I suggested doesn't have a "central" wiki, but just the
individual group wikis which are all of equal rank (none more central
than the others). One other point in case this is not clear already:  When you set
up wikis in groups mode, every group in your class will automatically
have the wiki with the same name.  So you need to give it a
generic name.  For example: suppose your project is about flowers
and you have groups working on petunias, sunflowers, and tulips. 
If you set up a group wiki named Petunia, EVERY group will have a
petunia wiki - even the tulip folks.  I would call the wiki
"flowers" and use the specific flowers as group names.  Then, the
choose wiki drop-down list will be clear because it gives the wiki name
and the group name: Petunias: flowers Tulips:flowers Sunflowers:flowers Not very elegant, but it is clear and I think it gives students the navigation tool you seem to want. Hope this is not too confusing. Russ

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a wiki infrastructure
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Russ, In the interest of time, I am using just one wiki this semester. There is one central wiki which links to group pages. We are going to use the honor system of only editing your own group page, of course having the history of edits will help to scare any would be sabatoers. I may try to modify the system for next semester, when my school will also upgrade our version of moodle. Gary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a wiki infrastructure
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Just getting started with wikis in Moodle. Very familiar with them via wikispaces and Wetpaint. I have a class project where each group of students (4-5) will work on a wiki, but haven't had any luck getting the Separate Groups to work. All students can access and edit all wikis still, even when I move kids individually into the separate groups. I'm missing the part of how the wiki gets assigned to the specific group of students. Suggestions? Thanks, Tom

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a wiki infrastructure
ResponsesInList.Text: Let's assume that you created a course with group mode set and then in the course created groups and then populated the groups. Then you created a wiki (erfurtwiki, dfwiki, nwiki?) and set the wiki type to groups (as opposed to student or teacher), and then set the Group mode appropriately (you indicate you set it to "Separate".) At this point if one of the students in Group A logs in they should only have access to the Group A wiki..... if that is not the case, please double check your steps

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki's are only created for one group - HELP!!
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there. Basically, I'm having a problem. I'm trying to create Wiki's for three Year 8 classes enrolled on a Year 8 ICT course; the three classes are enrolled on the course as three seperate groups. Now, whenever I create a Wiki it only ever assigns it to one group and doesn't give me any options that I can see to change this. This has the effect that only that group can access the Wiki's properly and get all the edited pages; the other two groups can open the Wiki's but they get a blank Wiki displayed instead. They can edit this and it saves the changed for themselves only. The Wiki's are set for "Groups" and "Seperate Groups". At the top of each one it says "Groups Wiki for 8AL" (8AL is the one group that everything gets set to, the others are 8CP and 8GH). Please can anyone offer any advice, as I am stumped!? Thanks in advance! - Nathan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki's are only created for one group - HELP!!
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Nathan When you have groups set on a wiki you see an additional 'Other wikis' dropdown on the top right of the screen. Similar to using groups in a forum you have to select the group you wish to "type to". Change this to each other group (eg 8CP then 8GH) to "start them off". The initial text you typed in the blank edit screen will probably already be in place for 8AL. I hope this helps Cheers Teresa

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki's are only created for one group - HELP!!
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a similar problem. I am using groups in the course, three sections . I have choosen separate groups for the wiki, but would like to choose students as the type. I read the post above, but when I click the dropdown I see all student wiki's. I know I'm doing something wrong, but what? How does this work?

ResponsesInList.Title: Student wiki with some default content?
ResponsesInList.Text: I would like to have a wiki for all students on a course, but have a couple of pages of default content to get them started. Is there a way of doing this? I can do it for a shared wiki, but not an individual one. TIA D

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Student wiki with some default content?
ResponsesInList.Text: You can use a txt file as teh starting point. This allows you to set up one page but not more than one. You could include the links to create the next pages and show pupils how to cut and paste information from subheadings in this file to the correct wiki pages. For example *[Health and Safety] **Which areas of computer use are covered by HSE legislation? **When did the law come in to force? **Whose responsibility is health and safety in the workplace? **What different topics are covered ***[Seating] ***[lighting]

ResponsesInList.Title: Grading Wiki Entries
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I am trying to find a solution for being able to grade Wiki entries and tie them to Gradebook. From an educational point of view, we are trying to motivate students to create a Wiki (because of the Wiki nature of allowing to build content over time) but also have the capability of grading what each student enters in the Wiki. The grade should be reflected in gradebook and be able to be aggregated as part of the overall grade. Is this possible? I have searched a few hours and have not found any information or plugin about this. I'm currently working with the standard Moodle eWiki installation but am open on upgrading to nWiki if that's the case. Would Moodle 2.0 have this functionality? Is it even worth considering building a plugin? I'm hoping someone can point me in the right direction on finding a solution for this. Thanks.
role: Picture of Joshua De la Vega

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Grading Wiki Entries
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joshua, last week I was with MD in Heidelberg for the http://Moodlemoot.de and we spoke about the grades in wiki for moodle 2.0 / nwiki ... Here's the deal. We (dfwikiteam) have designed and developed ( in this case thinking is the tougth part ) a way to grade wikis and integrate it with the gradebook and the moodle philosopy. We are testing this feature and I don't want to release it until is stable and is well documented for you guys to try it. I hope to be able to release it ina few weeks. Best

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Grading Wiki Entries
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ludo, Thanks, I am really looking forward to test this functionality.  I guess it wouldn't make sense to develop a custom plugin for this if you have already progressed this far.  Please keep us posted when this feature will be available. Thanks.
role: Picture of Joshua De la Vega

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ludo, In response to this, has it been released now? How can we get our hands on it? Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Grading Wiki Entries

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki has broken (back)links
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, i am new to moodle and right now i am assisting a teacher with a course.. He created a "seperated-groups" wiki and now there is one major problem: Somehow as soon as you add a new page to the wiki (independent of which group), there is a link on the new page under referring links, however its not the correct link linking back to the start-page but instead it links to a non-existing site/a site with no content. One thing that i can see is that the correct start page has the linkending "page=%20%20ISD-Wiki" ("page=++ISD-Wiki" also works) and the incorrectly linked to page has the linkending "page=ISD-Wiki". Under orphaned pages the incorrectly linked to page is listed, but when i delete it, it just reappears. The page is described as empty and there is also an error saying the page type is neither BIN nor TEXT... Can somebody give me hints with this, what could be the cause of this problem what could i do to try to fix it? Thank you, Robin

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki Module Headings problems
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi All, I've just started using Moodle, so I am still a bit new to the whole thing. I'm planning on using the Wiki module to create a planning document. However, I've bumped into an issue with regard to the formatting, particularly with headings and subheadings. According to all the documentation, if I put two equal signs around the text that I want as a main heading, it should be done automatically. However, when I do that, it seems as if the wikiwords is getting the signal to turn it into "preserve formatting" ie. everything inside the equals signs appear in "courier" or some sort of typewriter-based font. It's a minor annoyance, I know... but I'm wondering if I shouldn't just use the straight up HTML only feature. Suggestions?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki Module Headings problems
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi john, as you can check out around this forum and in the moodle newsletter 2 there is a new wiki module that is replacing the default module. This module enables headings just like in mediawiki and generates a TOC. Just like this: http://morfeo.upc.es/crom/mod/wiki/view.php?id=22 Cheers

ResponsesInList.Title: Double-editing the wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: What if two (or more) people are editing the wiki at the same time?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Double-editing the wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: ...which ever one saves last will be the most recent version! Neither would have each other's edits while they were working, so something would get lost in the newest version. But, you can always look back to the previous versions. This only effects the page that is being edited, not the entire wiki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Double-editing the wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey! I just discovered that its actually much smarter than I thought! What happens is this. If I open a version for editing, and before I save, someone else saves a new copy, I won't be able to save mine. It will tell me to use the 'back' button on my browser and cut my changes out of the editor. Then I can open the new copy and reapply my changes. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Develop 5 FAQs
ResponsesInList.Text: 1)Q. Can an 18-year-old student excuse his/her own absences? A. yes 2)Q. can an 18-year-old student leave the school campus at his/her discretion? A. yes, but only with a valid excuse. 3)Q. Do parents and legal guardians retain their educational rights if the 18-year-old student still lives in their house? Who ultimately makes the final decisons? A. No, Even though the student may still live with the parents or legal guardians and is claimed as a dependent, parents or legal guardians only have access to records, but can no longer make any decisons for the students. 4)Q. If an 18-year-old student needs to be transported to the hospital for further medical treatment and is denying treatment, can that student make the final determination or should his/her parent be contacted? A. Since the student is now considered an adult, he/she has the right to make the decision to refuse treatment. 5)Q. Can parents or legal guardians have access to their child's student records even after the child turns 18 years of age or becomes an emancipated minor? A. As long as the parents or legal guardians claim the child as a dependent on their federal income taxes, they retain the right to access their child's student records.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ending student additions to a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Darren, You can prevent students from editing the wiki by overriding permissions for the student role and setting the capability mod/wiki:participate to 'prevent'. Please see Override permissions for more details.

ResponsesInList.Title: Ongoing assignments with infinite accountability.
ResponsesInList.Text: I am running a translation class, where the students progressively will (I hope) revise their translations of Vergil's Aeneid (or at least the parts on the AP syllabus). I want them weekly to submit their latest translations including the new lines for the next week, but also any revisions they make to their previous efforts. I want to be able to see any changes they make, and to be able to trace any versions back to their original efforts, in case I suspect plagiarism. I considered using the multiple file option of the assignment task, and allow them to resubmit any number of new files (versions), but it seems that a better option might be to use the wiki and have history to show me the versions. A couple of issues occur to me: Will I get notifications when they change things? And will this be too much, if they edit online? Is it possible to compare arbitrary versions of a page, like on mediawiki, or is it just two sequential versions? Can I take a snapshot on the due date, to be sure that assignments are properly characterized as on-time or late? Is this the best way to do all this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ongoing assignments with infinite accountability.
ResponsesInList.Text: Did no one have an opinion on this question?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ongoing assignments with infinite accountability.
ResponsesInList.Text: 1. The wiki won't send you notifications, but it will keep a record of changes and the times. 2. I believe you can compare any two versions (or at least any past version with the present) 3. You can go to the last edit made on the due date and see the work done. The wiki module hasn't totally impressed me and I hear it will be getting a big update in Moodle 2.0. You cold have them work on a wiki and then every week have them copy the current version and paste it into an online text asasignment.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ongoing assignments with infinite accountability.
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes I agree that a wiki is your best bet for managing successive versions. We use OU Wiki because the NanoGong HTMLArea works with it (Moodle 1.93 - you should test this first in other versions) allowing audio annotations which might be useful for translation feedback. The wiki allows comparisons between any two previous versions (not just sequential versions), and it also allows you to revert to any previous version. The only downside is that it doesn't have a mechanism for assessment/grading, but then perhaps taking a snapshot copy and submitting it in a proper assignment might be better as it would generate a gradebook entry. An alternative to the wiki might be a forum (which is gradable), but this would only be practical for shorter texts. Regards, Mike Smith, Brisbane

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki links do not turn blue, they vanish into plain text when they exist
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm running Moodle 2.2 and testing out the Wiki for use in classes next week.  I'm running TeX and algebra filters. The wiki works fine, but links vanish into plain text from red once they exist rather than turning blue.  The links work fine if one can then find them. Is there a simple setting or fix to this?  I have not been able to search and find something on this problem. Many thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki links do not turn blue, they vanish into plain text when they exist
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ted, Does this mean that all your links in all blocks turn back to grey text after you have visited them? If that were the case your theming could be better! I'm not a Wiki expect but it sounds to me as if the css theme settings for links aren't doing you any favours. If the colour (color) setting for a:visited is the same as your ordinary text then they will certainly turn to plain text after the page is defined. If you are using Chrome browser then you can right-click (or CTRL-click) one such link and choose Inspect element to see what the settings are. You should also be able to change the colour temporarily here to see what effect that has. Similar things are available in in Firefox if you have Firebug installed as an add-on. To make permanent changes you need to edit the css. But if you do that in the theme's style.css you may affect all links. You can also work with the wiki's style.css in /mod/wiki/style.css. You should not open this file in a word processer such as Word, but in a text editor or a special css editor (a text editor will do fine). Start by saving a spare copy of this file (in case of disasters). Find the entry that begins: a.wiki_newentry and replace it with: .text_to_html a:link { color:purple !important; } a.wiki_newentry:link { color:deeppink !important; font-style: italic; } a.wiki_newentry:visited { color:turquoise !important; } Save the file and refresh the page. Do you get strange colours now? This should allow you to narrow down what you want. But note, you may also have to go into the Admin settings -->Theme settings and switch on Designer mode, otherwise you may not see the changes. This is one of many good reasons for not doing this on a live site, it will slow the site down. Hope this helps a bit. --John

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki's & Groups
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Everyone, I have a course set up that has 30 different sections . I would like to set up the Wiki's so that each individual student ONLY sees their work and no one else's. Currently, it looks like with sections set up, a student has the opportunity to see the Wiki of their classmates in their section. I can turn this off by turning off sections, but then that takes away the ability for the admin to see the Wiki's broken up by section, and also takes away the ability to look at the grades in the grade book by section. Is there a way to keep separate sections, but make it so that the student ONLY SEES their wiki? Thanks, Mark

ResponsesInList.Title: Disable smileys
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi! I'd like my students to use the default wiki in 1.7 to publish and exchange source code (or is there a better way?). No problem when camel-case-links are disabled and you allow plain text. But there is somewhere a filter for rendering smileys and so you have to use the edit-mode to get the real source code. Is there any way to disable (even hardcoding) rendering of smileys in the wiki module? Thank you! Regards, Stefan

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki doesn't save when set to student, visible groups in 1.7
ResponsesInList.Text: I've just been using the standard wiki with a class of students writing essay plans and they have run into trouble saving their work. One student received a message saying that he couldn't save his wiki because another student was working on it and lost what he'd been writing, another student ended up with someone elses' work on her wiki page and several only had part of their work saved. Is this normal when many people try to save concurrently under this setup, or is it a new problem with 1.7? Matt

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki doesn't save when set to student, visible groups in 1.7
ResponsesInList.Text: Matt, several students can work on the same wiki at the same time so long as they are all working on different pages (all pages must have a unique name otherwise links will be created e.g in your case if they all tried to create a page called essay plan, only the first one to save would create the page and everyone else would create links to that page....) I have found that it is best to create the first page of the wiki and include every students name in [] brackets so that when they click on the ? after their name a unique page is created in their name. If they add further pages to their page each page name should be unique, so perhaps get them to add their student number or initials to the page name. Hope this helps. Nigel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki doesn't save when set to student, visible groups in 1.7
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Nigel, that makes a lot of sense. I kind of assumed that when I set it to 'student wiki' that it would make one wiki page for each student automatically as suggested by the fact that the drop-down contains all of the students names and that was more or less what the pop-up help thing suggested. Iwould expect to have to use your technique if I had set it to 'groups' and 'No groups'. Did I misinterpret this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki doesn't save when set to student, visible groups in 1.7
ResponsesInList.Text: Matt, You are corrcect, if you set Type to Student then they should each have their own Wiki. I have been doing it this way for ages as a way of providing student feedback. I set type to student and group mode to no groups. This then ensures that the students cannot see each others entries.

ResponsesInList.Title: Exporting data from a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text:
Can data from a table on a Wiki page be exported as CSV (text separated
by commas or tabs)? I have the following problem. We have a project
where it is necessary that all people participating in the creation of
materials can keep track of the codes and names given to documents that
are created by other members of the team. This is necessary because we
want to build some sort of database with information about the
documents and the documents must have a unique code number. People who
create new documents must know whether the code already exists for a
particular document and assign a higher number if this is the case. Excel files work very well for this purpose but the great inconvenience
is that one must download them and upload them again once they are
modified. Since there might be many people working at the same time
that might be a problem. I thought that creating a table on a Wiki
could be a good solution. And here is the reason for my question. Every
once in a while we would like to export the data in the table to be
able to feed it into an excel file or perhaps some data base aplication
but I don't know whether this is possible with a Wiki. Does anybody know the answer to this question? If this is not possible,
does anybody know of some possible solution to this problem? Thanks very much. Josep M.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting data from a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I haven't tried to export a large table but I have exported wikis containing tables into HTML and then copied the tables in an excel file without any problem. The problem, though, was more about filling in the table in the first place as some people (students in my case) may prefer to have 'ready-made' cells rather than having to type the '|' themselves. Françoise

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting data from a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm showing my ignorance, but how does one do that. How does one export a table from an HTML document to an excel file? Thanks. Josep M.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting data from a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Just highlight the table(making sure that all the cells are highlighted), copy to the clipboard and paste into an Excel worksheet. Françoise

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting data from a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks a lot, Françoise, I didn't think it was going to be that simple, but your solution does work rather well. Somebody else on a different forum suggested also using the data > import data > web query option in Excel. That didn't work, however, probably because the page is within my Moodle site and it needs a password to access it. Josep M.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting data from a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I tried what you say but the presentation is wrong in excel (see next example). I'm working on macintosh (Safari 2, Firefox 1, Firefox 1.5, excel 2004). For example, for the following table in the wiki: Title 1 Title 2 Title 3 row 1 col 1 row 1 col 2 row 1 col 3 row 2 col 1 row 2 col 2 row 2 col 3 row 3 col 1 row 3 col 2 row 3 col 3 row 4 col 1 row 4 col 2 row 4 col 3 the result with a copy/paste in excel is: Title 1 Title 2 Title 3 row 1 col 1 row 1 col 2    row 1 col 3 row 2 col 1    row 2 col 2 row 2 col 3 row 3 col 1    row 3 col 2 row 3 col 3 row 4 col 1    row 4 col 2 row 4 col 3 After the first cell of each row, a return is added. So the presentation of the table is wrong. Perhaps, may be from the coding of the return on macintosh which is different on windows. What do you think about that ? Last minute : the problem is solved using internet explorer. However, microsoft stopped the development of IE on macintosh since few years. So, I would like that the problem will solve with a another web browser like Firefox. Thanks in advance for your help. Christian

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating an Initial Page in a Student Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm not sure that I can solve your problem, Jim, but I have done what you are trying to do before when creating a simple ePortfolio. I created the page in a Wiki, toggled to the html code and then copied and pasted this into a Word document. I saved this as Text Only and left off the extension (as the final wiki used this file name as the name of each student's wiki). I uploaded this into Files and then created the new Wiki, selecting this file to create the initial page. It worked for me..... regards, Kate

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating an Initial Page in a Student Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Unfortunately, the current erfurtwiki (I assume that is what you are using, but if it is not you need to let us know that ASAP) is really not adequately documented and the fact that a new wiki has been adopted does not encourage investing time in the current one. One of the sources of continuing confusion with respect to student wikis is that once the teacher creates the student wiki, and attempt to edit the wiki's first page will only impact the teacher's instance. Can't tell if this is what you are confronted with, but this is often the source of confusion. As Kate suggests, there is a method that is, well, a bit obscured for creating student wikis that allows for multiple pages, but it also might help you to see the difference.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating an Initial Page in a Student Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: We've run into that problem as well -- faculty can't edit a "student" wiki. We've had to use these 'not too intuitive' settings -- "group" wiki set to "no groups". There doesn't seem to be any way to edit wiki type once it's been set up... best to you, deb

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating an Initial Page in a Student Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jim you have probably solved or given up on this one, but I had a similar problem and eventually worked it out. You do indeed set up an initial folder, with one or more of the pages that you would like the wiki to be pre-populated with in that folder. The files must be text format but they should have no file extension. You then upload them to wherever you need, create the wiki activity, select the specific file you want to start with. All pages created with the links in square brackets work because they point to files with identical names (e.g. [foo] will successfully create and link to a file called foo, but not one called foo.txt. So obvious once I thought about it but at least it is here for anyone else searching on this problem. Cheers Ed

ResponsesInList.Title: Evolution and support for Wiki 2.x
ResponsesInList.Text: Wiki 2.x is on Moodle 2.0. Jordi Piguillem (Pigui) and I will be working on its evolution, support and maintenance. Future developments, features, documentation and other things will be organized in the tracker under the Wiki 2.x component and usually assigned to my user ( http://tracker.moodle.org/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=granludo ). Now I'm getting the house in order, but soon the tracker will show up very much the current Wiki 2.x roadmap and priorities. So this forum and the tracker will be the way to report bugs, issues, and request features. Please let's use the "tag" Wiki 2.x because we happen to have a bunch of wikis.

ResponsesInList.Title: searching ONLY current wiki version
ResponsesInList.Text: consider this scenario in wiki search: the search feature in wiki module searches in all versions of the wiki , but, the search result displays only a link to the latest wiki version (current wiki) only , after the search process, when the user clicks on the result link (wiki link) it would display the current version only and the user may get confused because the current version may not contain the word he was searching for, but when the user navigates to history tab, and goes through old versions of the wiki, he will find the word he was searching for in one (or maybe more) old versions of the wiki (and of course the word will not be highlited for this case so the user would search for it manually). so for this scenario, the result must display links for old versions of the wiki if these versions contain the search word. so I think the search wiki feature is unreasonable if this scenario happens (and it really happened with me), is there a way to search for words ONLY in the current version of wiki and then display the link for this wiki? should I change something in this line of code: if (! isset ( $_REQUEST [ "content" ]) && ( $dquery [ "version" ] = @ $_REQUEST [ "version" ])) { $dquery [ "forced_version" ] = $dquery [ "version" ]; } this line is on mod/wiki/ewiki/ewiki.php file .. thank you so much in advance. P.S. moodle version 1.9.9

ResponsesInList.Title: Migrating separate student wiki to wiki 2.0... big time dilemma
ResponsesInList.Text: In a point in time Skodak decided not not support separate student wikis... and all the UPC team exclaimed "Yay!" and we had a beer to celebrate it. Separate student wikis create weird dilemmas to deal with, because students enroll and unenroll. And yet, pedagogically, there is no point to have a non collaborative wiki going on. So we don't support it... Yay! But... there are separate student wikis out there in Moodle 1.x wikis and even on nwiki setups. So... We cannot throw away that content or somebody will be mad at me. The proposed solution : - we create a group with the teacher(s) and the student owner of the wiki, and place the content there.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Migrating separate student wiki to wiki 2.0... big time dilemma
ResponsesInList.Text: My reasoning was that other modules also need this mode of operation - "separate students". Since 1.9 we have the groupings that were designed to extend the uses of groups and allow exactly this. It is still marked as experimental, but groupings will be enabled in all 2.0 (only groupmemebrsonly will be kept experimental). The workflow would be pretty simple, first go to group admin UI and let Moodle create new grouping with one group for each user in the course. Then create a new wiki and set the grouping there. Everybody will have his/her own wiki. This should be fairly easy for upgrades too. If we decide to implement separate student wikis the problems are: * a lot more access control + more complex db structure * we need new UI for user selection so that teachers may actually access the user wikis * we need to handle cases where users are enrolled/unenrolled in the middle of the course * we can not change the mode of wiki from user to group * other modules need to do the same in order to keep consistency The coding and maintenance costs would be higher, on the other hand we would have a feature that probably no other wiki has and probably very few ppl use in the real life, also the UI would be cluttered with extra controls and the wiki would not be consistent with the rest of our modules. I personally think we should stop abusing modules for something they are not designed for, wiki is by definition a collaboration tool, so we should imo encourage group work in wiki and just describe potential workaround in case somebody really wants to use them in a different way. If somebody needs a personal notepad with wiki syntax support, it could be a My Moodle(dashboard) block. We should also concentrate on grading of work done by students in wikis, this could be best done as new gradebook reports that other modules may share. Another example is the Forum module, it could be hacked to support one-on-one teacher-student communication, but it would be an ugly hack with many problems, so instead I created the new consultation module. News forum type is yet another example of problematic - there are so many differences in news and forum discussions that it will be significantly easier to create News module instead of trying to fix the current new forum subtype. We had a little disagreement with Martin over this issue, unfortunately I do not remember if I managed to persuade hit the last time we discussed this ;-)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Migrating separate student wiki to wiki 2.0... big time dilemma
ResponsesInList.Text: As I said Petr... Yay! For me the only issue is the migration, so no data gets lost, and I think we have pretty much covered it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki and Excel
ResponsesInList.Text: One of my science teachers wants to have an excel spreadsheet pasted into a wiki for students to enter data.  However, when I paste it in the wiki, the excel formulas don't work. We cant use Google Docs, because it is blocked by our district filter.  Any ideas?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki and Excel
ResponsesInList.Text: I guess I am surprised that you thought the excel formulas would work, but have you thought about asking the district to allow you to access google docs either by just killing the blacklist entry or via a district google domain ? Of course if district IT refused you could a) simply tunnel to your own proxy or b) just have the students access google docs on their iPhones - LOL There is the ability to do calculation with asciimath, and given some time you could kludge together a calculated table - if you want to explore that install asciimath and check out the calculator

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki and Excel
ResponsesInList.Text: I should have worded that differently.  Is there anyway to embedd an excel spreadsheet, so it can be edited. Thanks for your input.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki and Excel
ResponsesInList.Text: I mentioned some possible ways to provide access to an online spreadsheet, but I don't know of any way to make excel specifically available via the web save perhaps through citrix. You could use another webbased app or even use thegoogle php api to do a editable noodle accessible spreadsheet, but that would be a gooddeal of work. I do believe that talking to your district IT staff about an exception for google docs or at least an exception for a google app district domain is a quick and easy way to address having access to googledocs. Btw , remember that there are conversion issues that arise moving back and forth from googledoccs to excel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki and Excel
ResponsesInList.Text: I should mention, since you did refernce excel. That you can publish excel spreadsheets as webdocs, but then you have to have ie to use them. There are quite a few resources on the web explaining how to move an excel spreadsheet to php and mysql , and if you have moodle you likely have access to both - faced with providing access to google docs or integration of your moodle with google apps as opposed to developing a php app or porting simple php spreadsheet, there is no telling what your helpful IT and EdTech staff might do.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki and Excel
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for your time and information.  I will share it with our IT.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki and Excel
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Deb, Two suggested work arounds. The first way would be a bit clunky if you had lots of students, but you could enable binary files, and upload a 'starter' Excel spreadsheet. Students would have to take turns to download the spreadsheet, add their dadta, and re-upload. At least the wiki organises things with date and time stamps so that the latest version could be downloaded and editted. Another alternative would be to have a table in your wiki with the format you have in the spreadsheet and have all the students enter the data. When all the data has been enetered you upload the spreadsheet with the formulas and they copy and paste the data from the wiki into it. Cheers, Sally Mack

It is really important to us to be able to have guests being able to edit wikis and complete Feedback surveys. Kind Regards, Marcel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Editing a Wiki as a Guest
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there. Guests can complete feedback surveys on the front page if you follow the appropriate settings - http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Feedback_FAQ However, guests can't edit wikis. There are certain things that the guest role does not allow and wiki editing is one - see the documentation here http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Guest_role The workaround is to make a real account -call it "visitor"; let your guests know the password and let them edit using that.

This CSS works for one single page: `.cmid-3547 h3 {font-size: 1.8em;}` This works for all wikis: `#page-mod-wiki-view h3 {font-size: 1.8em;}` But it only affects the veiw.php-tab. When I edit a page it looks different. How can I change the edit.php-tab as well? I tried this: `#page-mod-wiki-view, #page-mod-wiki-edit h3 {font-size: 1.8em;}` Unfortunately this changed the menu and other elements as well.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Custom CSS for edit-page in Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I use Moodle 3.11.12 and the Boost Theme. I don't like how the Wiki looks in Boost and want it to look more like Wikipedia. So these are all my changes so far: `.cmid-3547 h3 {` `font-weight: 400;` `font-size: 1.8em;` `margin-bottom: 0.5em;` `border-bottom: 1px solid #b2b2b2;` `padding-bottom: 3px;` `}` `` `.cmid-3547 .wiki_headingtitle h3 {` `font-weight: normal;` `border-bottom: none;` `padding-bottom: 0;` `margin-bottom: 0;` `}` `` `.cmid-3547 h4 {` `font-weight: 300;` `font-size: 1.5em;` `margin-bottom: 0.25em;` `border-bottom: 1px solid #b2b2b2;` `padding-bottom: 3px;` `}` `` `.cmid-3547 h5 {` `font-weight: 600;` `font-size: 1.2em;` `margin-bottom: 0.25em;` `}` `` `.cmid-3547 img {` `max-width: 100%;` `height: auto;` `}` `` `.cmid-3547 code {` `font-size: 100%;` `}`

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Custom CSS for edit-page in Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: If you inspect the page, you will see html code similar to body id="page-mod-wiki-edit" class=" etc You need to replace the id with a # and the class with a . so the selector is #page-mod-wiki-edit for the edit page and #page-mod-wiki-view for the view page any changes to CSS will affect everything on that page so you need to be more specific. You have specified a particular wiki, .cmid-3547 - so changes will only affect that one wiki and not all wikis on your Moodle. but . cmid-3547 h3 will affect all h3 tags on the page. If you only want to target the elements on the edit page, eg. h3 tags, then use #page-mod-wiki-edit.cmid-3547 #region-main h3 {

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Custom CSS for edit-page in Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank a lot. I found the mistake in my original code. WRONG: #page-mod-wiki-view, #page-mod-wiki-edit h3 {font-size: 1.8em;} Correct: #page-mod-wiki-view h3 , #page-mod-wiki-edit h3 {font-size: 1.8em;} That's why it was styling all elements on the page. Here is my complete Custom CSS for the Wiki Activity: https://github.com/margomius/moodle-wiki-custom-css

ResponsesInList.Title: contribution: PostgreSQL tables for WIKI
ResponsesInList.Text: Where can we contribute ? maybe a dumb question, sorry didn't had the time to read all the dev. info. mod/wiki/db/postgres7. sql Written by Pim Koeman, Wittenborg-university, Deventer, The Netherlands the moodle_ prefix can be replaced by any prefix Warning : compiles on postgres 7.4 untested on moodle functionality --// cut here //-- CREATE SEQUENCE moodle_wiki_id_seq INCREMENT 1  START 1; CREATE SEQUENCE moodle_wiki_entries_id_seq INCREMENT 1  START 1; CREATE TABLE moodle_wiki ( id int NOT NULL default nextval('moodle_wiki_id_seq'::text), course int NOT NULL default 0, name varchar(255) NOT NULL default '', summary text NOT NULL, pagename varchar(255) default NULL, wtype varchar(255) NOT NULL default 'group', ewikiprinttitle int NOT NULL default 1, htmlmode int NOT NULL default 0, ewikiacceptbinary int NOT NULL default 0, CREATE TABLE moodle_wiki_entries ( id int NOT NULL default nextval('moodle_wiki_entries_id_seq'::text), wikiid int NOT NULL default 0, course int NOT NULL default 0, groupid int NOT NULL default 0, userid int NOT NULL default 0, pagename varchar(255) NOT NULL default '', timemodified int NOT NULL default 0, PRIMARY KEY  (id) ); CREATE TABLE moodle_wiki_pages ( pagename VARCHAR(160) NOT NULL, version int NOT NULL DEFAULT 0, flags int DEFAULT 0, content TEXT, author VARCHAR(100) DEFAULT 'ewiki', created int DEFAULT 0, lastmodified int DEFAULT 0, refs TEXT, meta TEXT, hits int DEFAULT 0, wiki int NOT NULL, PRIMARY KEY (pagename, version, wiki) );

ResponsesInList.Title: Wikiexport: some questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear wiki developers, we are developing virtual environment for university thesis writing and thesis supervising for Finnish university students and their supervisors. We think Moodle would be probably best platform to our environment and we are starting our own development work. We are very interested about Wiki and its development like dfWiki. In dfwiki there seems to be some very interested features. Wikiexport is important feature to our project. So, I am asking your help in following questions: 1) When exporting Wikipages, is it possible to include ALL links in Wiki? We have tested Moodle's current Erfurt Wiki, and there is a problem because you can only import "downward" links. Referring links (breadcrumb trails) are not included when we have tested wikiexport. So if you look your exported wikipages in browser, you can go from one wikipage to another, but you cannot come back via wiki's links. 2) It would be useful to export wikis to pdf- or rtf. Is anyone developing solutions to this? 3) When exporting wikipages to html/pdf/rtf, it would be also useful to replace Wiki's CamelLetters with normal text. Is there solutions to this? TIA ,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wikiexport: some questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jani, first of all wiki (efurt Wifi) and dfwiki are completelly diferent modules and they almost don't share code ( only in the backward compatibility ewiki editor mode ). In dfwiki we have the import / export feature and the backup/restore feature wich integrates into the moodle backup system. I prefer the import export feature because it allows me to replicate wiki contets to any course or moodle installation. In the next two weeks we'll release a new dfwiki feature that will allow us to import data from old efurtwikis to dfwiki (extracting it from the moodle backup files). PDF and XHTML export is scheduled for next month. If you use dfwiki in html editor or dfwiki editor mode you don't need to use CamelCase, you simply use double brackets for links . Regards Marc

ResponsesInList.Title: Vast: Re: Wikiexport: some questions

In dfWiki XHTML export, is there solution to link export problem I described in my first message?  I have been testing dfWiki at your Moodle site's sandbox and it looks really great! regards Jani

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Vast: Re: Wikiexport: some questions
ResponsesInList.Text: There's allways the option of creating page synonims in dfwiki so CamelCase can become "Camel Case" and a search an replace tool can be used to change CamelCase links to Camel Case or Camel Case.. Regards Marc

Is there somewhere else I should be looking for Moodle modules? Thanks for any and all suggestions!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki confusion
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sarah, I have lots of questions about wiki as well, so I can only answer #3 and #4. I hope to hear some other answers, too. 3. There is no documentation that I can find about wiki in the official documentation or Matt Riordan's Teacher Manual 1.3. You might contact him and see if he has a new version 1.4 coming out and could he send you an early draft. To explain wiki to other teachers and students, I simply call it a "group document". In other words, a group of people can individually edit and re-edit the content. 4. New modules (such as Form, blog , etc.) under development are mostly available in the nightly build of Moodle version 1.5dev. If you have a separate server which you reserve exclusively for experimenting, then you can go to Downloads and try this one. It is unstable, which is why they are not available for general download yet. A few modules which have been under development for a while and are fairly stable (Book, Hotpot, Questionnaire) are available for special download under Add-on Modules in the Download section. By the way, I have another question about wikis. If two or more people edit a wiki at the same time and then save it about the same time, what happens? Which version gets saved?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki confusion
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Don, I have an updated manual based on 1.4.1 that I am determined to get out on Friday (the 17th). I am almost embarrassed how long it has taken me to update it, but this has been a busy couple of months. -Matt

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki confusion

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki confusion
ResponsesInList.Text: "If two or more people edit a wiki at the same time and then save it about the same time, what happens? Which version gets saved?" Only one can save at any given time. The second person gets a message saying that the wiki is being edited by somebody else and can then copy the changes and paste them in the latest version. It actually works pretty well as far as I could see from my students's use of their group wiki (I had 10 group wikis with 3 to 5 students in each group). Françoise

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki usage
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the explanation, Francoise. So a wiki requires turn-taking. Student1edit >> Student1save >> Student2edit >> Student2save >> Student3edit... and so on. It is not like a physical blackboard/whiteboard where many contributors can simultaneously make a comment. I wonder if online "whiteboards" operate like wikis or like their physical counterparts. This means when I ask for evaluation comments at the end of my face-to-face class, I should not use a wiki. I should use a forum (with setting to one-person/one-comment). Then everyone can make a comment and save it at the same time.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki confusion
ResponsesInList.Text: I'll limit myself to question no. 3: One nice source of info on the wiki phenomenon is the Wikipedia. Their listing for "wiki" can be found at: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wiki It contains some nice tidbits on the etymology of wiki, the underlying wiki philosophy (make it easy to fix mistakes, rather than make it hard to make mistakes) and some of the pros (wonderful collaborative environment) and cons (vandalism) of wikis. Cheers, Mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki philosophy
ResponsesInList.Text: On the pros and cons of wiki: it should be used in a high-trust environment. In other words, only have a group work in it *after* they have built trust among themselves or you sense trust has developed. Needless to say, group wikis should often be closed to group members alone. Note also that if a wiki has been accidentally or deliberately messed up, you can go back to an earlier version to start over.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki philosophy
ResponsesInList.Text: You can set the group wikis as separate and then switched to visible at the end when the wikis are ready for "public view". Other groups can then see every other wikis but cannot edit them. I found it really good to give some space to groups to work together on a project, knowing that nobody else (apart from the teacher) would see it until its completion.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki philosophy
ResponsesInList.Text: >> You can set the group wikis as separate and then switched to visible... Yes, I agree this is a very powerful procedure. Groups should wrestle with a problem/project independently at first, coming up with their own original responses privately. Then when they are ready to revise and rebuild, it is helpful to see models/results of other groups. Therefore, maybe a step or two before the "end product", we can turn the wiki on publically.

ResponsesInList.Title: Heads up: Wiki 1.x interwiki disabled by default
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, wiki 1.x (the one distributed as part of Moodle 1.x core), has one undocumented feature: interwiki links. And it has been there, anonymously, since the beginning of the module. Recently we "discovered" ( MDL-19460 ) it was causing some annoyances to pages named "Wiki: whatever" and others, causing the module to automatically redirect to other URLs (interwiki ones). As long as the feature is an undocumented one (and unsupported) we have decided to disable it by default. So starting next weekly build (June 17th 2009) those interwiki links won't be working anymore under Moodle 1.x. In any case, as last resort... if somebody was using such feature it's possible to enable it again by defining: $CFG->wiki_allow_interwiki = true;

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki omitting anchors in external links
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everybody, I want to link to a specific part of an external page like this: http://docs.moodle.org/en/Wikis#Creative_Wiki_practices If I add a link like this inside a wiki page, it links only to the first part of the link ( http://docs.moodle.org/en/Wikis ) but omits the anchor (#Creative_Wiki_practices). (By the way, we have the same problem on this page. Just look at the first link above.) Is there a solution to my problem? Thank you for your answers! Best regards,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki omitting anchors in external links
ResponsesInList.Text: We used to be able to specify anchors within Moodle 1.8.x, e.g. [ https://eureka.westmont.edu/mod/wiki/view.php?id=2848&page=FAQ+-+Students#nopasswd ] . (This is a live, public page.) However, apparently since upgrading to 1.9.2+, when a wiki page is edited either in HTML mode or using WYSIWYG HTML editor, all anchors are stripped from the resulting code, leaving only <a></a> where <a name=nopasswd></a> should be. Previous versions of the page in the mysql database have the proper anchor tags. Anyone else seeing this problem? John Rodkey

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki omitting anchors in external links
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm having this problem, does anyone know if there was a fix? r.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki omitting anchors in external links
ResponsesInList.Text:
For the record I discovered the following: HTMLpurifier was casuing this problem. I had to update HTMLPurifier Lite to Version 4 and then I added 
```text
$config->set('Attr', 'EnableID', true);
$config->set('Attr', 'EnableAttrID', true);

to the constructor in HTMLPurifier.php

Anchors work perfectly and the formating of my page is retained!

R.
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ouwiki templates and images
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Carl, I'm the lead developer for ouwiki so I can probably shed some light on your issue. What version of the plugin and Moodle are you using? The most recent version of the plugin for your specific Moodle version should be used to ensure you have all bug fixes etc. These can be downloaded from https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=mod_ouwiki - note for ouwiki you should raise questions there or issues on the github project , not on this forum as it's not monitored. If you're having problems with template images you should check they are in the template zip file (assuming the template is a zip file, if it's just xml you are using a version of the plugin that doesn't support images in templates).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ouwiki templates and images
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm using Moodle 2.7 so I'm guessing thats the issue.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ouwiki templates and images
ResponsesInList.Text: Changing the reg expression near line 215 of entirewiki.php from '#<img.*?src="https://moodle.org/pluginfile.php/193/mod_forum/post/1160402/(.*?)".*?/>#' to '#<img.*?src="https://moodle.org/pluginfile.php/193/mod_forum/post/1160402/(.*?)".*?>#' (i.e. removing the closing slash) seems to have solved the problem in Moodle 2.7. For some reason img tags had closing "/" in 2.6 but not in 2.7. Maybe this is a 2.7 bug?

ResponsesInList.Title: Where or what is the "ImageUploading function"?
ResponsesInList.Text: In the wiki editing help page it is mentioned, that in inserting images you can use either [http:://link.to/image.jpg] or the "ImageUploading function". Where or what is this function?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Where or what is the "ImageUploading function"?
ResponsesInList.Text:
In the edit view of any wiki page, there is an upload button, following a
field to browse for the relevant documents. It's below the save,
preview and cancel buttons at the bottom of the page. Or at least it is in my wiki! There is an image insert button in the html editor but I think this will only give access to existing site files for students. Only admin / teachers will be able to upload through this route. Hope that helps. Sinéad

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Where or what is the "ImageUploading function"?
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't see the Upload button, not in "No HTML" or in "Only HTML" modes. I'm the admin of my Moodle, version 1.4.4... With the HTML editor + "traditional" way I could add a picture to the wiki, but I want to use "no HTML" mode, and in that mode the traditional way means a couple of more steps...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Where or what is the "ImageUploading function"?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I'm having trouble with the upload function, too. When I change the settings to "allow binary files" the Wiki page dissapears. An error message "page not available at the moment" is created. My students need to upload files to a Wiki -  how can I manage this? Thorsten

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Where or what is the "ImageUploading function"?
ResponsesInList.Text: I have found the solution: I have changed the setting "binary file" in the administration menu ("page settings" or so) of each coursemembers-wiki (where you can change the settings for read-only, wiki turned off,...). That caused the error and the wikis to disappear. Now, I have changed the setting "allow binary data" in the main setup menu of the wiki. That worked without any problems. Thorsten

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Where or what is the "ImageUploading function"?
ResponsesInList.Text: As Sinead commented, the imageUploading works for teachers so students will have access to those images the teacher chooses. Students can have access to their own images when they upload those images as described by Sinead (above, message). For them to have access to those images, they type: [internal://ufo.gif] where ufo.gif is the image uploaded.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle+wiki+blog+planning

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle+wiki+blog+planning
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Antonio, The activities you speak of are now in the works for version 1.6 of moodle.  I suggest you make a test server and download the the most current 1.6dev download to see how these modules are progressing.  If you can't, then wait 1-2 months when version 1.6 beta comes out and then make suggestions to the programming team.

ResponsesInList.Title: Ética y Moral
ResponsesInList.Text: Ética es la reflexión teórica sobre la moral. La ética es la encargada de discutir y fundamentar reflexivamente ese conjunto de principios o normas que constituyen nuestra moral. Moral es el conjunto de principios, criterios, normas y valores que dirigen nuestro comportamiento. La moral nos hace actuar de una determinada manera y nos permite saber qué debemos hacer en una situación concreta. Es como una especie de brújula que nos orienta, nos dice cuál es el camino a seguir, dirige nuestras acciones en una determinada dirección. La brújula nos indica el camino. En la vida hay que intentar no perder el norte.

ResponsesInList.Title: Layout Suggestion - SiteMap

Would anyone else find it useful to have the sitemap as a link, similar to the view, edit, history links that are right on top in moodle1.4beta? most of my wiki documents are outlines with heirarchy, using a new wiki page for a new 'branch'. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Do not allow entry with @ to render as a mailto link
ResponsesInList.Text: Matt - From the help file (/lang/en_utf8/help/wiki/howtowiki.html) if you don't want a WikiWord or a !http://www-address (or [anything] inside square brackets) to become a HyperLink then just prepend it with a exclamation mark or a tilde !NoHyperLink, ~NoHyperLink ![no hyperlink], !! http://nolink.org/

ResponsesInList.Title: Unexpected interaction between Wiki and groups
ResponsesInList.Text: I do realise that this is in the documentation, but I recently discovered that there is a confusing interaction between the "Individual" Wiki and the group set-up on a Moodle page. It's not immediately obvious that, when a Wiki is set up on a course that has groups enabled (either Separate Groups or Visible Groups), the default setting of the Wiki also inherits the groups setting, and once students have created content under the Groups setting, converting to a true individual Wiki makes all of that content unavailable. I know it might not be possible to change this in the system, but I think a clearer description in the documentation of how these settings interact would be helpful.

ResponsesInList.Title: Is it possible for a teacher to protect a Wiki page temporarily to keep people from changing it.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Would you know if it is possible to temporarily protect a page in WIKI? That would help teacher of our organization. I do not seem to see any option, neither in the standard Moodle Wiki nor in the OU Wiki. Thanks Imbu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is it possible for a teacher to protect a Wiki page temporarily to keep people from changing it.
ResponsesInList.Text: You can, of course, turn off access to the entire wiki (it will still be available to the teacher), but I don't think you could just freeze one page. I'm pretty sure that an open page is uneditable by any other user, so you could just leave it open somewhere...a crude approach, surely. Otherwise, you can, of course, simply depend on the ability of a wiki to revert to an earlier version to protect existing content. Modifying roles associated with the wiki could also remove editing capabilities for the whole wiki. That's all I've got...good luck!
