ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki vs. Book
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all - I'm teaching university students and would like them to be able to collaborate in summarizing the content of the lecture so that eventually, they have a resource to prepare for when exam time comes. Would you recommend using a wiki for each lesson , or a book and have each lesson as a chapter? (of course I can use a wiki for entire class or a book for each lesson but that sounds less appealing) Thanks,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki vs. Book
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi David Wiki would be a better choice because every student can manage to edit one wiki but book is a resource, which a student can't add or edit. Resources only have read permission a student can't interact with it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki vs. Book
ResponsesInList.Text: At one level, Sakshi is right, but at another, the response does not really answer the question. There is also the idea that data requires its own structure, it demands it essentially. What are you presenting? Static knowledge, googleable content? Informative opinion? Dynamic information? Peer interaction? Wiki or Book, what about forum? Your response also needs to take heed of what you are trying to accomplish in the course - not just the learning outcomes, but the processes involved along the way. That should determine what tools you use. I am currently developing alternate responses to these questions and finding a set of solutions, not just one size fits all. Essentially, Moodle does one job, another tool does another job that Moodle is not designed to do. Seems to be working so far... but we shall see. So let your information and your processes define how you respond to each circumstance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki vs. Book
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks to both of you. I want students to be able to contribute their knowledge and basically use wiki as a replacement to their lecture notes. Ideally, at the end of the course, they would be able to print it out and use it as reference. For future courses, I'm still debating if I should give them access to the previous semester material and have them enhance it, or develop it from scratch. A book as you mentioned is more structured, but I definitely want students to own it so seems like I will go with a wiki. I would be interested to see your solution Colin, perhaps you can share.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki vs. Book
ResponsesInList.Text: Perhaps that might be possible David, but for the moment, I am not sure the other tools I am using are not all available outside Australia. Most are, but some are local products - you may have equivalents though. One of the tools is called DayMap, from a Melbourne company. Essentialy an SMS, it also has a small LMS module that is more or less a credible wiki and not a lot else. I am not sure that they will be selling internationally yet but I imagine it won't be long. I am developing a solution that meets our local laws regarding storage of data, as well as promoting positive learning outcomes. It also uses MS-Sharepoint which we are turning into a local repository - so not a lot is going to be stored externally. Moodle is, hopefully, going to be used for resources and online testing, If they can get Mahara up in that environment, then that will be for eportfolio and social networking with other common open source tools for more specific purposes - Wordpress for one. All locally stored and we can develop them to suit our need. One snag, Sharepoint 2013 is not being co-operative right now so the whole strategy could be brought undone by it. As I said, we shall see.

ResponsesInList.Title: Is it possible to add MS Office documents to a Wiki?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is it possible to add MS Office documents to a Wiki?
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes ... I think... Yes, if you copy-paste the contents of a Word document into a Wiki page using the icon "Clipboard with a W" from the second row in the palette of tools. Format from the original document should be preserved. If you see a tab "Files" in the Wiki page, then you are able to add a Word document to a Wiki. I'm using Moodle version 2.2.x or older and I can. Not sure about previous versions. You could also use an external link (such as "share docs" from Google, where students can create documents of various kinds and insert their links in a Wiki. For this, use the "chain link" icon from the third row in the palette of tools. HTH

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is it possible to add MS Office documents to a Wiki?
ResponsesInList.Text: Sure! Add a piece of text, and link it to your documents. Whilst adding the link you can also upload any type of file. Or do you want to embed the Office file right into the page? Like embedding a pdf via "file resource"? I think thats not possible. Sample

ResponsesInList.Title: Are wikis the best way to post documents in moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello all, I am trying to get over 25 procedure documents into our moodle system. Currenlty the documents are all hard copy, with the content being stored in source files (with all sorts of extensions: pdf, word, excel, html, etc). I could just post a pdf of the document but i was hoping for somthing a little more fluid. Would wikis be a good way of keeping 1 source for all the content of a docuement? If so is there a way to break up sections and pages within a wiki so you could print off specific areas instead of the whole document? I understand what wikis are but my experience is limited, Any help would be appreciated. cheers, Mike. PS. if there is a better mod for this I'd love to hear it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Are wikis the best way to post documents in moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Wiki's would be a good choice. You will have to create the structure by inserting links (doc, section, page) and users will have to navigate it. Printing two consecutive pages could be a real pain. Prototype it first to see if it meets your needs. Also have a look at the third-party Book module . Each one of your original documents would become a chapter in the book, and sections would become sub-chapters. Book is printer-friendly. For an example of a Book, see the Finnish Moodle Teacher's Manual .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Several students editing a Wiki at the same time?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey there - first up, itsbgreat to see you trying to use a Wiki.  But what you seem to have attempted to do is akin to if you can imagine that you had a car with 30 driving wheels, then how many people could steer it at one time?  At least that's my simplistic analogy. I suggest you come at this from a different angle - instead of thinking I want to use a Wiki, now where can I use it IN MY CLASS?  Why not think of a series of scenarios where you think students could collaborate OUTSIDE the classroom and set a task that requires that to be done, say, before the next lesson . It's 'horses for courses'. Also to lessen the impact of your problem - you could always try creating GROUPS within the Wiki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Warn your students: beware of reload after edit
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there. The current standard wiki and nwiki versions handle pretty well the concurrence issues. You can't edit a page that other student is editing. BUT. If a user edits a page, saves the changes, and then another user changes the pages... if the firts user goes to the toilet and presses reload when he/she comes back.. then the second edition is lost. Is still in the history but no more in the current page. We need to think about how to deal with this ... I've got some ideas but there are more serious issues to fix before. So warn your students about the reload button!!! Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Removing "slash slash" at the bottom
ResponsesInList.Text: We have v1.9 and also get the '//' at the bottom of each page... and can't help much with your first question. We have wikis and users put up with the //. We are looking forward to having a go with NWiki in 2.0 To edit the help information go to Administration > Language > Language Editing and select the ' Edit help documents ' link. The dropdown provides all the help files, search for the appropriate file e.g. wiki/howtowiki.html... Edit the 'Local modifications' by copying/pasting the content from one of the Master packs. Your local modifications when saved will override the master pack. I hope this helps Teresa

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Need your advice!
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Perry thanks for using NWiki, this week someone reported a data loss in NWiki preciselly because he upgraded moodle and replaced the nwiki files. I would do it simpler. Just create a folder with only the the contrib modules you installed and your config.php When upgrading moodle cpy th moodle distribution and inmediatelly e-copy the contrib modules of your installation. since nwiki replaces the MOODLE/mod/wiki directory another precaution would be to be sure to remove this directory from de moodle distribution before upgrading. Seems obvious, but is not, be sure to back up ( database and files) eerything before applying the smallest patch. Cheers L.

ResponsesInList.Title: CSS and eWiki

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: CSS and eWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: This is more of a "themes" issue. You'll need to create your own custom moodle theme and then over-ride the css for paragraphs. I haven't tested this, but something like the following might work: #wiki-view wiki p { margin-bottom: 10px; } --Stuart.

I attempted to define "p {..." in this file but made no difference. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: CSS and eWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: What version of moodle are you using and is it the standard wiki or have you installed the new wiki (nwiki)? You are right about the css I posted up. It did nothing. The following actually works, but only for moodle 1.8+ with the nwiki module: #mod-wiki-view div.box.generalbox p { margin-bottom: 50px; } Let me know if you are using any different versions and I'll see what I can do. --Stuart

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notification of new comments
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi John, The instructions I created do work now. I get notifications of new comments in Wikis. It's a bit tricky, but it works.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notification of new comments
ResponsesInList.Text: I wrote these instructions for myself yesterday, and to share, once they work. Being notified of a new comment in a wiki. Go to Administration => Reports => Event monitoring rules Click "add a new rule" Fill in the form and Save changes. To be notified of the events you have created rules for, click on Event monitoring page, at the bottom of the page. Select a course from the drop down menu. At the bottom of this page you will see your events that you have not subscribed to. Choose the modules that your rule applies to from the drop down list on the right. If you choose "All instances" all events of that module in that course will trigger a notification. When the event occurs in the chosen place, you will get a notification in the usual way, i.e. your bell icon at the top right will light up. I created comments in several wikis that I created notifications for and didn't get any notification.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notification of new comments
ResponsesInList.Text: Yesterday I created these instructions for myself, and to share, once they work. They are not working at the moment. Being notified of a new comment in a wiki. Go to Administration => Reports => Event monitoring rules Click "add a new rule" Fill in the form and Save changes. A title you'll see in the list of rules Choose Wiki from area to monitor Choose Comment created from Event Write a description if you wish Choose how many of these events need to occur before you are notified Choose how long after the events take place before you are notified Edit the notification if you wish, but keep the default fields. Save changes To be notified of the events you have created rules for, click on Event monitoring page, at the bottom of the page. "Select a course" from the drop down menu. At the bottom of this page you will see your events that you can apply to the chosen course. Choose the wikis that your rule applies to from the drop down list on the right. If you choose "All instances" all new comments on all wikis will trigger a notification. When the event occurs in the chosen place, you will get a notification in the usual way, i.e. your notification bell at the top right will light up. In your Profile, choose Notification preferences. Make sure the check box “Disable notification” is empty. At the bottom of this page, Event notifications => Notification of rule subscriptions. Turn this on. -------- I have followed my steps, created comments in the assigned wikis. No notifications. The only notification I get is that I have created a new rule. Unlike other notifications, it does not have anything clickable in it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Embedded video
ResponsesInList.Text: I am using the Wiki module as a way of posting student video tests so only they and I can see those tests. I load the videos into files by grade level, have the students create their Wiki, then use the hyperlink controls to link the videos to the student's Wiki. The problem I am encountering concerns the way videos are linked to student wikis. My videos are created on Mac as a ".mov" file, and Moodle is automatically embedding them in the body of the wiki. This creates some problems loading each wiki and presents problems if I want to place multiple videos on one wiki. It also messes up student formatting of their wiki. I have tried a number of solutions to try to prevent video embedding, but none (at the code level and otherwise) has yet to work. Anybody have any ideas about how I can still used ".mov" files but prevent automatic embedding? Thanks, Kevin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Embedded video
ResponsesInList.Text: afaik there is no way of doing this. You can use QT Player Pro to Export your .mov to mp4, don't recompress, just "pass through" the video and audio. iTunes can also convert .mov to m4v (same as mp4), use Advanced>Create iPod or iPhone version. But the data rate will be about 1500 kbps. Change the m4v extension to mp4, Moodle seems to like it better. Then the href link to the mp4 will not embed the movie, it will just provide the link to the movie in same window or a new window. At least that's how it works on our install of Moodle. Of course everything needs to be tested on Mac Safari and Firefor, and Win XP/Vista IE and Firefox , but I think it will work.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Embedded video
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for the suggestions! I will give this a try and see if it solves my problem (particularly the suggestion to change the m4v extension).

Upon clicking on the link, the url appears in the address bar (http://domainname/moodle/mod/wiki/view.php?id=2602) and then the spinning wheel goes for 30 seconds (always 30 seconds, I timed it) and then stops with a blank page showing. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blank page when viewing a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Most probably the wiki page takes to long to process (more than 30 sec.) Can you try these suggestions: If you are the maintainer of the machine go to your php.ini file and adapt max_execution_time = 30 to a higher value. If you can't control the php settings of your webser you can try to put Best is not to make one large wiki page but split them in smaller one's

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blank page when viewing a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Herbert, Thanks for responding. I had suspected a time out issue even before I posted. When I arrived at my office this am, I upped the max_execution_time to 60. Seems to have solved the problem. I also sent a note to the teacher about large wiki pages. Thanks again. Peter

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki for case studies
ResponsesInList.Text: Quick question - when you say "set up a discussion but the discussion doesn't allow uploads of PPT or PDF files", are you talking about forums? They do allow such uploads, but it might be  your max upload size is not big enough to allow uploads of large power point files. YOu could check this in the forum settings and also the course settings (and check with the admin) Do you know what version of Moodle you are using? Go to a page where you have teacher editing rights and click the " Moodle docs for this page' link at the bottom - it should tell you a number which is the number of your version of Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: The problem of chinese character for OU wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone, I had tested ou wiki 2.5 on moodle 1.9.10+ and found some problems. When I added new section to page or create a new page,if I typed some chinese characters as the section name or page name ,for example "校園"or "研究",after clicking the buttons "add" and "save changes",all the content is lost in this page,what's wrong? Does this module "OU wiki " agree with unicode character? Any one can give me suggestions? Thank you very much. Jing-dong wang

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: The problem of chinese character for OU wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I also got this in private message and replied to it, however just to clarify, my understanding (& experience here after a quick test) is that in general, OU wiki does work correctly with Chinese characters and any other unicode characters. If anybody else has insight into this, please let me know. --sam

ResponsesInList.Title: 回應: Re: The problem of chinese character for OU wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sam, Thank you for your reply. I had recorded a video file of operational steps like your message. Please click this addresss and watch the attached video file. The test is on moodle 1.9.11+ with mysql ,and 2.5 ouwiki. When I had added a new section name,all of the content is blank,and no error messages are found. This phenomenon is found only for some chinese characters,like "校園" or "研究". What's wrong? Thank you for your help. Jing-Dong Wang

ResponsesInList.Title: 回應: The problem of chinese character for OU wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Maybe the function "str_replace" can't be used for two-byte character(chinese,japanese....). The function "mb_eregi_replace" is more proper for two-byte character. Jing-Dong Wang

ResponsesInList.Title: 回應: The problem of chinese character for OU wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi sam, I have found a solution for this problem. I have modified the function "ouwiki_format_xhtml_a_bit"  in ouwiki.php. At line 2399,the original code is $content=preg_replace('/\s+/'," ",$content); and replaced by the new code $content=preg_replace('/[\r\n\s]+/u'," ",$content); the parameter u is for multibyte character . Thank you very much for your help Jing-Dong Wang

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 回應: The problem of chinese character for OU wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you. I don't understand why this solved the problem for you because this regular expression only works with ASCII characters which are not altered in UTF-8. (Also as noted, the problem doesn't occur for me including using the same strings.) However it is good that it's solved it. One possibility is that the version of the underlying 'preg' library is different on our different systems and this somehow means that it requires the /u flag on yours, but not on mine. Strange. Oh well. --sam

ResponsesInList.Title: YouTube embed appears twice in a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text:
I don't know if this should be reported as a bug. Here's what I just discovered after a teacher reported that an embeded (with Multimedia filter) YouTube video was displayed twice in a wiki. If you use the URL as the link text, it will be converted to a hyperlink in the wiki, causing a double link. Like this: ```text

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W4uipnBkj-4

``` You must replace the text to fix it:

some texte

Using Moodle 2.6.2

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: YouTube embed appears twice in a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Is it the same problem discussed in here: A <nofilter> tag in the forum? https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=218330 ? The solution I found is linked to the last post in that thread.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: YouTube embed appears twice in a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Similar answer to the one from Visvanath Have you tried turning off the autolink filter for the wiki?  Should be doable from Administration block -> Wiki administration -> Filters Ensure you turn off the filter "Convert URLs into links and images". Otherwise, when editing the wiki page with the TinyMCE editor on, select the link and click the "No auto link" icon. Hope this helps!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: YouTube embed appears twice in a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks a lot for your replies. Sorry to get back so late. I just had a baby. I cannot see how to disable wiki autolinking in Moodle 2.6. There is no wiki filter and no global settings for wiki activity. François

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: YouTube embed appears twice in a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: YouTube embed appears twice in a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I got around this by entering something other than the URL as the text of the link. In html, your href should look something like this (with "video" being variable, as long as it isn't the url of the youtube video): href="https://youtu.be/K1hbhuUdjWU">video Not like this: href="https://youtu.be/K1hbhuUdjWU"> https://youtu.be/K1hbhuUdjWU ;

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 1.9.3 w/NWIKI 2.0...no save in IE
ResponsesInList.Text: We are running Moodle 1.9.3 and this is the fix from our programmer: The tags.lib.php wiki_tags_print_editbox() method closed off the editor's form above the Save, Preview, and Cancel buttons. This made the buttons invisible to IE. There is a form close below the buttons in any case, so this is a bug in nwiki. I also fixed another bug in the wiki_tags_save_tags() method to handle the case where an argument to the method is null. If you drop in the tags.lib.php file attached above in mod/wiki/tags (replacing the one that's there) this should fix the problem with IE. Note that I'm using the latest NWiki from the developer and installed it per his instructions (that is, after removing the existing wiki in 1.9).

ResponsesInList.Title: Wrong words (eg. "++") are matched as CamelCase in spite of "Disable CamelCase Linking"
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi, Moodlers. I've been in the face of two strange phenomenons under using ewiki on Moodle1.8. Under checking "Disable CamelCase Linking" on ewiki (Moodle1.8, 1.7, ...), Camel case words (eg. UsingMoodle, WikiModule...) does not match as Camel case. On the other hand, unexpected words (eg. a++, a]+[, ...) will match as Camel case. For example: for ($i = 0; $i < 100; $i++)    : HTML editor ->  for ($i = 0; $i < 100; $i ++ ? )  : View page (ewiki) '++' is linked for new page. I don't expect! Another phenomenons is as following. For example: a[] is an array. a[1]   : HTML editor -> a 1 ? : View page(ewiki) : I want to avoid. a![1]  : HTML editor ->  a[1]  : View page (ewiki) : That's right. a[]   : HTML editor ->  a ? : View page(ewiki) : Oh? a![]   : HTML editor -> a![]   : View page (ewiki) : Oh No! a![ ]  : HTML editor -> a[ ]   : View page(ewiki): huum...O, OK? (How to correct these problems?) The cause of these problems is on following code, in mod/wiki/ewiki/ewiki.php if ($moodle_disable_camel_case) {
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_L", "");
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_U", "");
    }  else {
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_L", "a-z_??$\337-\377");
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_U", "A-Z0-9\300-\336");
    } EWIKI_CHARS_L/U are used for detecting Camel case words. These constants are used on regular-expression as follows, "wiki_link_regex" => "\007 [!~]?( \#? \[" style="border-right:0px;border-top:0px;vertical-align:middle;border-left:0px;border-bottom:0px;" alt="[^<>\[" src="http://moodle.org/filter/tex/pix.php/25443382e01c0fa744dccb716a12d8bc.gif" /> \n]+\] | \^[-".EWIKI_CHARS_U.EWIKI_CHARS_L."]{3,} | \b([\w]{3,}：)*([".EWIKI_CHARS_U."]+[".EWIKI_CHARS_L."]+){2,}\#?[\w\d]* | ([a-z]{2,9}://|mailto：)[^\s \[\] \'\"\)\,<]+ | \w[-_.+\w]+@(\w[-_\w]+[.])+\w{2,}   ) \007x", and $value = preg_replace_callback("/((\w+：)?([".EWIKI_CHARS_U."]+[".EWIKI_CHARS_L."] +){2,}[\w\d]*)/", "ewiki_link_regex_callback", $value); Most important part is ([".EWIKI_CHARS_U."]+[".EWIKI_CHARS_L."]+){2,} . If we set that the "Disable CamelCase Linking" is On, both of EWIKI_CHARS_L and EWIKI_CHARS_U become null (blank?). Therefore, regular expression will become to ([]+[]+){2,} . [*] (eg. [A-Za-z0-9]) is meta symbol that means character class. [*] is not allowed that the inner part of brankets is null. /[]+[]+/ is interpreted as [ ]+[ ] + , then the render of ewiki view page will misinterpret non-Camel case word as Camel case word in spite of Disable CamelCase is On. /[]+[]+/ means that a word matched with the pattern consists of a character ']' or '+' or '['. I propose a modification for this problem. if ($moodle_disable_camel_case) {
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_L", "\t");
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_U", "\r");
    }  else {
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_L", "a-z_??$\337-\377");
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_U", "A-Z0-9\300-\336");
    } This patch means that CamelCase word consists of 'Carriage return' and 'Tab code', for example : '\r\t', '\r\t\r\r\t'. This experssion is safe since these strings shall not appear in plain text generally. I'm using ewiki in Japanese. After applying this modification I have no trouble under setting 'Disable CamelCase Linking'  On. If you are also in face of this problem, let's try this patch.

ResponsesInList.Title: How to disable display of table of contents in a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, Because of a nasty error in the way the table of contents seems to work I want to disable the table of contents generation for a wiki page. I have been searching in both configuration and documentation, but I didn't find anything. The reason I want to disable the TOC is that it doesn't allow for the same text to appear more than once and generates visible errors. The kind of layout I have is: instrumentname handling other things instrumentname handling other things etc. Anyone an idea how to either remove the TOC or the errors? thanks in advance! cheers Maurits

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to disable display of table of contents in a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Maurits, Disabling this wont help fix the error but it will hide it away. I'm not a Wiki expert, but if you go into: /mod/wiki/parser/markups/wikimarkup.php and search for protected function generate_header , then a few lines below that you have: if ($level < 4) { If you change this to: if ($level < 1) { ...the Table of Contents will disappear from ALL wikis. It should come back if you reverse the changes. Regards,  John

ResponsesInList.Title: moodle 1.9 - Wiki Types - differnce between wiki and OUwiki

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: moodle 1.9 - Wiki Types - differnce between wiki and OUwiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Maria, we used the moodle wiki for a number of years and have been using the OU wiki since September 09. The OU wiki is much more stable / reliable after multiple edits. The old wiki generated lots of superfluous code after each edit, especially if using tables. From my experience OU wiki works best in firefox . Firefox and IE work in different ways when you use tables and the full screen editor. If you are going to write user guides you will probably need an IE version and a firefox version. In general, we are happy with our move to the OU wiki. Hope this helps. Nigel

ResponsesInList.Title: Would a Wiki Work Best? Class and Individual Portfolios
ResponsesInList.Text: I am teaching American History II (American History from 1865 until the Present) at a community college.  I have created a theme for the course where students apply and work at a hypothetical historical newspaper.  Each assignment relates directly to this theme, from there application to the newspaper and their vertical progression through the company.  At the end of the semester, the student will have completed a variety of assignments.  I want to create a individual portfolios and a class portfolio to track the development of this course and create a research tool for writing an article on the pedagogy of this course. Would an individual wiki work well for a individual portfolio, where an each assignment gets an individual wiki page? Could I use a group wiki for the entire class where they each post there assignment under the corresponding assignment title?  What I am thinking is that this group wiki would have several main pages, such as Applicant Cover Letter, Obituary Assignment, Internal Memo etc... Then each student would get an individual subpage.  So then there would be say 25 sub pages for each main page.  I want to organize the student work in a way that I can access easily in the future. Any advice would be much appreciated.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Would a Wiki Work Best? Class and Individual Portfolios
ResponsesInList.Text: Bit of an old post, but for anyone's reference, we've just created a portfolio plugin that takes content from any moodle course across a site & brings in into the moodle blog . See https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=222275 for more. Chris

Creating hundreds of wikis manually would be pretty painful, so I'm looking for alternatives. I thought manually editing the MySQL database might be the easiest way (generating some nice big SQL file which would create everything in one go) but it seems more complex that I'd hoped and could easily mess up the whole thing (in addition to tables mdl_wiki, mdl_wiki_entries, mdl_wiki pages and mdl_course_modules, there's a fairly obscure entry in the modinfo field in mdl_course and probably some others I haven't tracked down). I've also had a look at hacking the php code to create the wikis, but tracing through the code is proving tough (it starts with course/modedit.php?add=wiki&... but my php isn't up to tracing it all through). I'm using Moodle 1.9.2 with ewiki. Any ideas? Thanks,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create multiple wikis in one go

There's certainly no supported way to do it. I assume that it would be possible to script it, but from looking at the code, I've just been unable to track down the functions that actually create a new wiki, at least in a way that would let me script it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create multiple wikis in one go

You can hack you course formats (weeks, topics, etc ) to create a new wiki if it does not exists. You wouldn't have to deal with Moodle database and every wiki will be automatically created on user "demand" (teacher accessing to his course). Hope it helps. DFWikiLabs, Pigui.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Murrary One popular FAQ I have used and seen work well is the Glossary Module . It has an FAQ display type so the concept is the question and the definition is the answer. You can then have key words and categories. I hope this helps Cheers Teresa

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What's the best way to make an FAQ?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Murray, I think it depends on how much knowledge they're going to need. I've made up a couple of Word documents I link to so students can see how to operate the system (basic version) and gain better understanding of/access to e-learning (advanced version). As a teacher I could find all groups, but when I changed my role to "student" I was also unable to see the final two groups. I checked in the groups settings, the groups DO exist. Any ideas? (I am using 1.9.2) Thank you!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Not all groups show in drop down menu, so students can't participate
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello We encountered the same bug, but have managed to trace it and work around it. This happens if you create a number of groups, then a wiki that is groupvisible. It seems moodle does not actually create the wiki instances until they are accessed. The work around: 1: Create everything as normal 2: Log in as teacher 3: Use the drop down menu to open each wiki (to force moodle to create the instances) This way the instances will be generated and available to all the students. I am also pretty sure that simply waiting for all students to log in and check their own wiki would solve the problem (but I have not verified this)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Seeing Wiki pages as admin or teacher
ResponsesInList.Text: Sorry, Swiki is another implementation of Wiki, I am just a demanding user of eWiki and give my comments to M&M. So my comment here is that I think teachers should have always access, because we are an educational setting not a wiki community. I use Swiki as a stand-alone program until this eWiki is fully integrated in Moodle. I like this integrated eWiki now very much: And I prefer the HTML-editor above the Wiki-simple-text-philosophy.. But this Swiki option (coomentbox) was very nice: the only thing a user had to do was place a commentbox symbol on the page, place his email in a "send me an email"" -field and lock the page. (Students can take ownership of a page when they put a lock on a individual page of a group-wiki.) A visitor sees then the locked page with the commentbox. As soon as the visitor types his comment and presses the comment-button under that box, the owner gets an email.There is no database behind it, pages are stored in XML -format. Another option I did like was the possibility for a webuser with editor rights to create a webform instead of the standard fill-in screen. The page-storing mechanism makes collecting the content of the forms to difficult, no database.. Swiki is a standalone server that runs on Mac,  Unix, Windows.. We used it for several years at our secondary schools to collect experience with collab-work on a website. Works great. http://minnow.cc.gatech.edu/swiki The program Swiki is written in the Smalltalk version Squeak. The pioneer Alan Kay is one of the founders. Their children project eToys is inspiring http://www.squeakland.org/ During meetings they play the game to install and run this Swiki-server in less then ... seconds.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Seeing Wiki pages as admin or teacher
ResponsesInList.Text: Alright, I double-checked the code and tested it. I was wrong; I implemented it such that teachers can edit any wiki - even student ones. So, if you're not getting that functionality, something's wrong. Now, there is an issue with changing the group mode on an existing wiki. I haven't figured out how to resolve this yet. If you were to change a group wiki, that was previously set to 'no groups' to 'separate' or 'visible', and it already had wiki entries, you would orphan that pages that were originally created. The effect you would get is that the teacher would always see the orphaned wiki first when they looked at the wiki. The teacher can see the real wikis by selecting them from the drop-down list. If the teacher edits the orphaned one, only they will see it. No students from the course would ever see the orphaned one. So, to summarize: A teacher can edit and view all wikis, regardless of type and group setting. Group wikis can be edited by anyone in the group. If the group setting is 'no groups', then anyone in the course can edit them. Group wikis can be viewed by anyone, for 'no groups' or 'visible groups', or by members of the groups for 'separate groups'. Teacher wikis can be edited by teachers only. If you are not seeing this functionality, make sure you have the latest code from CVS , and try a fresh wiki. Don't change the group setting once you have entered wiki entries. Let me know any anomalies you see. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Seeing Wiki pages as admin or teacher
ResponsesInList.Text: Since the teachers can edit student wikis, they should also be able to create them for the student. I will put the code in for this today. Now, some other questions: Do we want to handle this differently for groups? Should the teacher be a member of the student's group to create the student's wiki? Should teacher editing privileges affect this? Should a teacher from a different group be able to view a student's wiki if groups is set to 'separate'? My thoughts: Editing teachers and administrators can view/change/create entries for any wiki. Non-editing teachers not assigned to a specific group can view/change/create entries for any wiki. Non-editing teachers assigned to a specific group can view/change/create entries for any wiki in their group, and view wikis in other groups for 'visible' groups. Make sense? mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Export - MediaWiki . . . Inport - NWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I have tried and tested NWikis ability to export and import XML files and is seams to work flawlessly. I then got the idea to try and export some pages from a MediaWiki site (WikiBooks) to be precise, and try and import them into NWiki ... Well you can all guess ... it did not work, however, after closer inspection of the MediaWiki XML file I realized that it should be possible to write a parser that would take the MediaWiki XML tags and replace them with NWiki replacements. There are many tags in the NWiki XML file that are LMS dependent, these are what makes NWiki more suited to our educational needs. I am guessing that if there is no corresponding tag in the MediaWiki file then they can be simply inserted with defaults. I am imagining a stand alone parser at the moment but I'm sure that this could be written into the php scripts that read in the XML files and it could be implemented transparently in NWiki. What do the rest of you wiki'ers think? Linds

ResponsesInList.Title: How can I upload an exel file?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi, I would like our students to access an excel document from the main
page of our course. I have not been able to make accessible from moodle. How can I upload it so it shows in the course window so that students can edit it? Thank you for any advice. Sarah

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can I upload an exel file?
ResponsesInList.Text: Sarah, This is straightforward and you don't need to create a wiki if you're looking for students to access the file as is from the course outline. To do this you should 'display a directory'. Here's how: Go to the Files area of your course (in Administration block) Create a new directory. It doesn't matter what it's called, but you might want to call it 'excel documents' click on it to enter the directory. Now you want to browse and upload the Excel document that you want to make available. Having done this, return to the main course outline and make sure that Editing is switched on. Find the weekly or topic block that you want to present the file in and choose Add a resource -> Display a directory Give the resource a name, perhaps, 'Excel files' and in the summary say what kind of spreadsheets are going here. Pull down Display a directory and choose the 'Excel documents' directory. Click Save changes. Now the contents of this directory will be displayed to your students when they click the resource link.

ResponsesInList.Title: What is Wiki and what can I do with it?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is Wiki and what can I do with it?
ResponsesInList.Text: Check this link out for one of the first wikis. Essentially, a wiki is a way for everyone to add content to a web page. They can create new pages, edit existing ones and see a change history of all of them. We use it to add an activity to a course that allows multiple participants to create and edit web pages. This implementation lets you specify who is allowed to edit and who can only view. Additionally you can multiple parallel wiki structures being maintained by different people / groups. mike

Now I'm looking at the delights of DFWiki and wishing I had it to use on my Moodle.  I've been poking around in the documentation but don't understand the basics of what I will need to do.  I assume I will download the DFWiki module. FTP it to my site.  Expand it on my site, and then...?  How do I get it into Moodle? Everything associated with Moodle seems to be so well documented that I'm certain this is documents some where, I just haven't found it. Thanks in advance for any assistance you can give.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: True Newbie wonders how to get DFWiki into her Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: HI Susan, the dfwiki zip file contains the files and directories that you have to copy into your moodle main directory (the mod, lang, and blocks directory, I think). Then you have to enter in your moodle app as admin user and then the module will execute its update sscrits. Just remember that right now dfwiki does not yet support postgresql , so you should be using mysql . Now you just have to add dfwiki activities or dfwiki courses. I recomend you use the last version, we released two days ago, is proiving to be pretty stable. Cheers and wellcome to moodle. Marc

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: True Newbie wonders how to get DFWiki into her Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Are there any step by step instructions for this anywhere? I'm struggling with follwoing exactly where to put which directory or what has to be done as an admin. To use dfwiki seems like the way forward but without *clear* (and i mean DLEAR, numbered, step by step without assuming anything) documentation of installation it just seems a little too difificult - I'm going to try piecing together the scant instructions to date and seeing what happens, and maybe documenting it. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: True Newbie wonders how to get DFWiki into her Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi steve... the dfwiki zipfile comes with 3 directories ( sometimes within a main directory called dfwiki_1.0_rev2006xxxx ...) mod lang and course you must copy this directories inside the main moodle installation dir. Then you have to enter into the "admin"  page of moodle logged as an admin user . Then dfwiki will start updating the database , as allways you install a new module. Then you can add a "dfwiki" activities in you courses. Feel free to use the dfwiki blocks by turning editing mode on... as when you play with your moodle courses... Regards Marc

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki and Copyright
ResponsesInList.Text: If one has a closed course that contains a wiki, is it legally enforcable to restrict students from sharing the content of that wiki beyond the course if it is stated up front that copyright of the material remains with the organization offering the course, with the exception that individual students retain the copyright of the material they themselves compose personally in the wiki?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki and Copyright
ResponsesInList.Text: I am not a lawyer but... The organization can enforce the copyright of its material, but cannot automatically act on behalf of the other students to enforce the copyright of the material they have created, as they retain this. You create the wiki Student A adds some content Student B copies A's content to a public arena You have no IP redress against student B, but student A does , as you've said that student A retains the copyright of the material they composed, which they would have done anyhow, unless they'd agreed otherwise. You might however want to phrase the AUP in such a way that you can expel student B from the course. It might be worth using a creative commons licence for the wiki stuff, as it would be difficult to identify who has composed the material, and thus retains the copyright, if it goes through a process of iterative editing.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki and Copyright
ResponsesInList.Text: I like the point that what a student writes belongs to them. My concern is not if a little bit of it slips out at the hands of the individual authors, it is the whole work that would be a problem. But since each individual owns their own copyright, they would have to work en masse to do that.

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki vs forum
ResponsesInList.Text: I would say one wiki would be enough, with separate pages for each issue. The front page should be the 'forum overview', with links to each issue. The problem with wiki as forum is that it is mainly a tool for collaborative writing, so it allows several users to write on the same pages. This is also one of the problems you see e.g. on wikipedia, where several authors write on each page, and thus creates a kind of discussion that can be very unstructured, commenting in between each other etc. Forums do not allow other users to change what another user has written. So for a wiki to be successful as forum tool, there has to be some guidelines easy enough for all to understand, and some moderators to ensure compliance. If you create separate wikis - this might make it easier for the users to handle different issues - you should add links on the pages between the wikis so it is easy to navigate between them. But it is important to design the forums/wikis with the users, to see how it best suits them Forums in moodle can be used the same way as forums in phpBB, depends on the settings. It looks like your forum is restricted who can reply - but this is not your fault, the standard news forum is normally for one way communication. Moodle forums have two settings that control who is allowed to post and reply, check them out. And one great thing with Moodle forums is that your users can subscribe to them to receive postings with email or via RSS feeds. So forum or wiki? I think it depends on how much effort you want to use to structure the communication. The forum tool is more focused, the wiki is more open. But to me it sounds like you would be best helped with the forum. /Ian

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki vs forum
ResponsesInList.Text: Ian: Thanks for your comments,I played with the forum idea some more and I think I have come to the conclusion that what I really need for this function is PHPBB. I found that I could like to my existing PHPBB site using the "add resources". I need the different levels of category and topics that php gives me and linking doesn't create that much of an issue with my users. I will continue to play with this package though since I need to create employee evaluation tests with it. Thanks Again Rick

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki vs forum
ResponsesInList.Text: You could add the glosary module to the list of possibilities. In brief, Forum : everibody could post. Anibody could edit THEIR posts but only during the next 30'. Nobody could edit the post of others (they could add new post as reply). Glosary : everibody could post. Anibody could edit THEIR posts allways. Nobody could edit the post of others (they could add commnets or new entries) Wiki : everybody and everytime could post and edit what they or others write.

ResponsesInList.Title: Simultaneous editing occurs in wiki with overwriting of data as result
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, We have discovered that the edit protection in the wiki of Moodle 2 is not watertight. Normally, if a (student) user tries to edit a (collaborative) wiki page that is being edited by another user, they would see an error message: " Someone is editing this page right now. Try to edit it in a few minutes. " However, experience has shown that nonetheless it is sometime possible for users to edit a wiki page simultaneously with as a result that the data of the user who saves first is overwritten by the one who saves last. Our tests have so far identified three possible scenarios: An interruption in the Internet connection. If a user, for instance using an unstable wireless connection, suffers a short interruption in his connection, another user can open the editing mode of the same page, provided they click at the right moment. A mix up with open browser windows or tabs If a user leaves the wiki in editing mode in one browser tab then opens another with which he/she also surfs to the wiki and then gets the view mode, another user can open editing mode for the same page even though the first user still has it open. Using the back button If a user edits and saves a wiki page, the pages becomes editable by another user, but the first user can use the back button of his/her browser to reurn to editing mode without encountering the error message. We wonder if anyone else has noticed these and other cases where the edit protection fails? And also if anyone has suggestions for improvements, apart from instructions to students for proper use of the tool. We use Moodle 2.3.2+ Rgrds, Paul.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Since updating my Moodle system via CVS last Monday (the 24th September) I and students have been able unable to upload files to Wikis - the default Wiki that comes with Moodle, not NWiki, DFWikii etc. When trying to the upload a file via the upload dialogue box below the HTML editor a new tab opens, but with no information about the file I wanted to upload. Normally, a text would appear which I'd copy into the editor to create a link to that uploaded file. When I try to upload a file via the attachments tab I get a the following 'error message' in the attachments page: uplrejsect This happens with all browsers and file types. This has been reported before: click to see previous related messages .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Unable to upload files to Wiki: [[uplrejsect]] error
ResponsesInList.Text: Just to confirm that we are also getting this error. Amanda

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Unable to upload files to Wiki: [[uplrejsect]] error
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Amanda and anyone else trying to use the default Wiki, In the absence of a solution to this bug (files can't be uploaded) I have come up with a workaround. Using the Database activity module I have created an 'activity' called 'File Bank'. Students upload their files to that, and then copy the URL for the file that they want to add or link to their Wiki. Students then access their Wiki and use the icons in the HTML editor to either add links to files in the 'File Bank', or embed images that have been saved in the 'File Bank'. This seems to work better than the original method of adding attachments to wiki pages. Hope this idea is of use to other moodlers.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Unable to upload files to Wiki: [[uplrejsect]] error
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, we had the same problem here at our end, but I concluded that I have to hack the code myself to get it to work. Now, the problem was in the file moodle_binary_store.php, which can be found within the directory /mod/ewiki/plugins/moodle/ The problem was that the save path and location for the file to be saved was created from the wiki name . I changed this to the following in the function moodle_binary_store_file: function moodle_binary_store_file(&$filename, &$id, &$meta, $ext=".bin") { # READ-Only global $_FILES, $CFG, $course, $wiki, $groupid, $userid, $ewiki_title, $cm; if(!$wiki->ewikiacceptbinary) { error("This wiki does not accept binaries"); return 0; } $entry=wiki_get_entry($wiki, $course, $userid, $groupid); if(!$entry->id) { error("Cannot get entry."); } require_once($CFG-> dirroot .'/lib/uploadlib.php'); $um = new upload_manager('upload',false,false,$course,false,0,true,true); if ( $um->process_file_uploads("$course->id/$CFG->moddata/wiki/$wiki->id/$entry->id/")) { $filename = ''; // this to make sure we don't keep processing in the parent function if(!$id) { $newfilename = $um->get_new_filename(); $id = EWIKI_IDF_INTERNAL.$newfilename; } return true; } error($um->print_upload_log(true)); return false; } I also changed this in the function moodle_binary_get_path: function moodle_binary_get_path($id, $meta, $course, $wiki, $userid, $groupid) { global $CFG,$ewiki_title; $entry=wiki_get_entry($wiki, $course, $userid, $groupid); if(!$entry) { error("Cannot get entry."); } $dir=make_upload_directory("$course->id/$CFG->moddata/wiki/$wiki->id/$entry->id/"); return "$dir"; } So, now it reflects the wiki->id and entry->id instead. It now works for us. Hope it will help somebody else to!

ResponsesInList.Title: the "code" tag seems to be not activated
ResponsesInList.Text:
hello, i'm working with the moodle wiki here on moodle.org and on my installation. paralell i work with some ewiki installations in another context . ewiki supports the "code" tag to be able to integrate code snippets in wiki pages. i noticed that the "code" tag is not interpreted in the moodle wiki. ewiki changes 'code' to 'pre class="markup code"', the moodle wiki lets it unchanged. in the ewiki documentation the difference between 'pre' and 'code' is described as follows: 
```text
#  use the 'pre' ... '/pre' 'tags' for a paragraph of 
preformatted text, that still allowed to use WikiWords and 
simple markup

# with 'code' ... '/code' instead you would really see text as 
you typed it, with square brackets and other escapes not 
garbaging your text
```
 could someone of the developer team please think about activating the 'code' handling as in ewiki? ps. the 'pre' implementation seems to have a bug in the moodle wiki. empty lines in the 'pre' block make the interpreter close the block before reaching the '/pre' tag.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Headers sent Error for newbie to Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text:
Still having problems with this? As it says in the error message, you are not allowed to execute /usr/bin/patch, because your service provider uses open_basedir restriction. The function is_executable returns false, and the plugin 'edit_patch' does not get loaded. This is the correct behaviour, I believe. Have you enabled 'debug' mode in your Moodle (configuration/variables/debug). If not, the warning should not appear and mess with your headers. If debug has been set to 'No' and you still get the warning, you can remove it by adding an error control operator (@): 
```text
  if (@is_executable( ...
```
 Regards, Jarkko.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: links to smb: url in wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: HI, the dfwiki parser automatically creates a link for the web adresses (starting with http ) we did'nt consider the smb protocol as one to be parsed. With dfwiki you can choose wich markup languages (dfwiki ewiki htmleditor )  when you create the page. Regards Ludo

ResponsesInList.Text: Linking to local files is widely considered to be a security hazard so the browsers are all dropping it. Pity.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Image link not transferring
ResponsesInList.Text: Do you have CamelCase linking enabled, and does the name of the file contain mixed case characters. I discovered this morning that if I uploaded a file called "MyPicture.jpg" to the wiki with CamelCasing enabled, Moodle would dutifully link the file name, which appears to have the effect of removing the source information from the image. The end result is that the image would show up in preview (which apparently doesn't try and CamelCase the images), but not in the wiki. When I disabled CamelCase linking, the image displayed properly. Ken Newquist Lafayette College

ResponsesInList.Title: How to transfer Wiki with content between courses?
ResponsesInList.Text: I want to copy a wiki to a different course. I tried with backup and restore, yet the restored wiki was completely empty except the description text field. Is this a bug or a feature?

ResponsesInList.Title: How to transfer Wiki with content between courses?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Martin, I guess that's a feature. Same will happen with a Forum, Glossary or Database activity. This has to do with the fact that the content in these activities is generally created by your participants, making this 'user data'. If you backup/restored the activity or course without the enrolled users, the user data will not be incorporated in the backup file. You can, though, anonymize the user data, and then create the backup file as a workaround.

ResponsesInList.Title: Standard version 2 Wiki doesn't seem to understand groups and groupings
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Is anyone else having problems with groups and the standard Wiki module in Moodle version 2? I'd like to be able to set up a wiki on a version 2 moodle system in which, "there is one wiki per group, students can change the wiki of their own group only, and they can view the wikis for all groups." When using moodle 1.9 and the standard issue Wiki I often set up a wiki so that small groups of students could collaboratively edit their own group wiki, and view the wikis of other groups (see the yellow cell in the table below). This does not seem to be possible in version 2. Either students are able to edit both their own group's and other groups' wikis, OR they can only edit their own group's wiki and not even see other groups' wikis. The settings for a 1.9 wiki to make this group collaboration possible were (also see yellow cell in the table below): Type: groups Group mode: visible Grouping : Grouping-A (this setting not necessary, but useful in courses with lots of groups) The Wiki settings in version 2 are different. These settings; Wiki mode: Collaborative Group mode: Visible groups Grouping: Grouping-A result in a wiki in which students can edit their own group's wiki AND those of other groups. I was hoping that these settings would emulate the 1.9 version described above (and in the yellow cell below). These settings: Wiki mode: Individual Group mode: Visible groups Grouping: Grouping-A Available for group members only: checked result in a wiki in which students cannot edit a group wiki (to be expected) but can edit their own wiki. They can also see the wikis of other students. The strange thing about these settings is that even with the "Available for group members only" checked, students can see a menu of all students and groups in the course, not just the groups in the relevant grouping. I have tried other combinations of settings, but none get the result I want and used to be able to get in 1.9. i.e. "one wiki per group. Students can change the wiki of their own group only. They can view the wikis for all groups". This is a bug, surely? For your reference, here are the Wiki types available in 1.9, copied from the help files of a 1.9 system: Wiki types (in 1.9) There are three wiki types: Teacher, Groups, Student. In addition, like any activity, the wiki has the Moodle group modes: "No Groups" "Separate Groups" and "Visible Groups". This leads to the following matrix of nine possibilities: No Groups Separate Groups Visible Groups Teacher There is only one wiki which only the teacher can edit. Students can view the contents. There is one wiki for every group which just the teacher can edit. Students can view the wiki of their group only. There is one wiki for every group which just the teacher can edit. Students can view the wikis for all groups. Groups There is only one wiki. The teacher and all students can view and edit this wiki. There is one wiki per group. Students can view and edit the wiki of their own group only. There is one wiki per group. Students can change the wiki of their own group only. They can view the wikis for all groups. Student Every student has their own wiki which only they and their teacher can view and edit. Every student has their own wiki, which only they and their teacher can edit. Students can view the wikis of other students in their group. Every student has their own wiki, which only they and their teacher can edit. Students can view the wikis of all other students in the course. Unless the group mode has been forced by the course settings, it can be set with the groups icons on the course home page after the wiki has been created. So how can this group wiki feature be emulated in version 2? _______________________ Environment: Moodle 2.0.2+ (Build: 20110413) php 5.3.3 MySQL 5.5.9

ResponsesInList.Title: OU Wiki to replace current wiki module?
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, the wiki module is listed as possibly being replaced by OU Wiki at some point in the future in the Roadmap . The question I would ask here is why was this not done in the transition from v1.9 to v2.0? I know I am being unfair, the amount of excellent work done by a lot of people, (none by me), should not be so casually dismissed, but as a fan of wikis, I am actually appalled that the Moodle wiki is so.. so... dowdy.  It was poor in v1.9, and did not fare any better in v 2.0. I understand there was a substantial debate around a new wiki for v2 but really, the end result is disappointing. I know the perception has always been that MoodleWikis should be course specific, but I would ask why? This may have been desireable a few years ago, but is it still so? For me, Moodle wikis can work at two levels, one is site wide, much the same as Forums and Docs do here, (but with a single login). The other is at a course level. Most educational institutions, and businesses for that matter, could well use a tool with that kind of flexibility. Wikis can be specific, and general, and as a place for all sorts of information. We are now well used to using Wikipedia as a source, but what if a school, for example, had the opportunity to develop a school wide Moodlewiki? What if a class of students had the ability to develop a single wiki for an ancient History class, and their teacher could use that as a fully annotated and referenced demonstration of student learning. Better still, could the teacher then not allow continued development of that wiki at a site level?  Over time, it could become an incredibly valuable resource for a school. Is this not what wikis should be? Rather than OU Wiki, why not use MediaWiki as Moodle Docs does? Why not fully integrate MediaWiki as a part of Moodle. Any comments or suggestions are most welcome.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: OU Wiki to replace current wiki module?
ResponsesInList.Text: I agree, I'd like to have wiki content that can persist beyond a student's course enrollment. We also see a value in being able to selectively publish some content for public viewing (i.e. viewing by users not enrolled in our institution).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: OU Wiki to replace current wiki module?
ResponsesInList.Text: That is not a use that I had actually thought about Elizabeth, but is a great suggestion. That would be a very useful tool in a lot of different contexts. Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: OU Wiki to replace current wiki module?
ResponsesInList.Text: It would be great to have stronger MediaWiki integration with Moodle. My  team uses both extensively. There are some education-focused extensions and initiatives related to MediaWiki, but nothing even close to Moodle. The current wiki plugins for Moodle are far to limiting.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: OU Wiki to replace current wiki module?
ResponsesInList.Text: I agree Nathan, the current wiki module is far too limiting. The idea of Moodle is flexibility, and there is, of course, strong argument that Wikis should relate to courses, as activities , but the broader picture is overlooked in that context . Flexibility should not always mean just within Moodle. The other important thing too is that there needs to be a single login policy. That does not happen in Moodle.org, and I do not understand why? It is likely if there is a embedding of mediaWiki into Moodle that the login process will be taken care of. Currently, in our circumstance, our students log into their computers/network, then to the internet, then to Moodle, then to a wiki (if we had one). Now, to me that is just putting barriers in place. (I know that there is a couple of programs that will change this, like iChain, but that assumes all network techs have a high skill set and that is not always the case.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki Wondering....
ResponsesInList.Text: When you work with a collaborative wiki in Moodle you have to consider a few things: What is the content you want to add in your wiki? In case you want to use some advanced features like some embeded activites, you will need to write a filter to do so. For instance, you can't embed H5P activities without a filter. How many people will edit the wiki at the same time. With the Moodle wiki only one person can edit a certain page at the same time. When working with students - who sometimes forget to save their work, this might cause problems, as other students will not be able to edit the same page. Choose the name of the main wiki page carefully, as you can't change it afterwards.

ResponsesInList.Title: ouwiki new release
ResponsesInList.Text: (For those who are not familiar with it, the OU wiki is an alternative wiki for Moodle 1.9. It does not replace the standard wiki but is an additional option. It works with the HTML editor instead of wiki markup and is designed to be user-friendly and simple.) I have done an updated release of the OU wiki today. Read information and get it here Not many new features but it does include bugfixes, including the one Glenys posted about in this forum! If you had problems trying to install an older version, please give this one a go. For those wondering what's happening in future, there are no major changes on the horizon. We are planning to add a couple more administrative features - including the ability to revert to a previous version without having to copy/paste it - in the autumn. Also just a note - I am posting this to the wiki forum because it seemed most appropriate, but I don't actually read the wiki forum (obviously, we have our own wiki, so most of it is not relevant). I'll try to remember to keep an eye on this post for the next few days. However, if you need to report a bug, please contact me directly by email/Moodle private message. --sam

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ouwiki new release
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, IS there a way to allow students to insert images into the wiki through the menu editor? Right now it only allows a reference to an image. Thank you Leo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ouwiki new release
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Leo, This isn't an Ouwiki problem but a Moodle problem : students can only insert images which are already on the internet, so they can't upload them directly. You can get round the problem, see this video Creating assignments in Moodle for Students to Upload files. Students can also upload images in the Database module. Cheers, Glenys

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki: How to restore changed or deleted pages
ResponsesInList.Text: Choose "Page Info". There you can revert changes. Shortly, some more tools will be added....

ResponsesInList.Title: Image links failing
ResponsesInList.Text: There are various threads about problems uploading images but I can find nothing recent on how to solve problems with image links failing. I had a student inserting an image (that resided on the web) with an address that ended Laughing_buddha_statue_Buddha_gift_m.jpg The image showed up correctly in the editor but only the alternate text showed up in the preview. I tried shortening the name and then it showed up correctly. However, when I experimented to find out the length at which it failed I found I could add letters and numbers until it was way past its original length. Further experimenting suggested length was not the issue but it was to do with the use of upper-case. In particular, if the name began with an upper-case letter it could not move away from upper-case and then back again; if the letter began with lower-case there was no such restriction. So, these are OK... ABcde.jpg ABCDE.jpg abcde.jpg

ResponsesInList.Title: Non collaborative wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Good evening all. In the olden days, it was possible to create a wiki that only the teacher could edit. I was fond of this as a way of providing an introduction to my site. But it seems to be no longer possible. Or are there settings that I am not aware of. Thanks in advance, James

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Non collaborative wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there. Well with the latest version of Moodle you have the Book module which is standard, but alternatively , take a look at question 1 of the wiki FAQ here http://docs.moodle.org/23/en/Wiki_module_FAQ

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Non collaborative wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, you could take away the permission for students for the activity (or indeed the whole site if you are Admin ... not recommended!) However, if you are creating a document that everyone should be able to read but not edit I think you would be better sticking with a Page - why not ? More complex requirements can be created with a Book or Lesson .

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle wiki timeouts/saving problems
ResponsesInList.Text: A couple of our students are reporting problems saving their content to the Moodle wiki (original flavor, Moodle 1.5). One reported getting this message: Edit this page 'GroupWork Wiki' Sorry, while you edited this page someone else did already save a changed version. Please go back to the previous screen and copy your changes to your computers clipboard to insert it again after you reload the edit screen. Curiously, SHE was the last person to have saved, so we're not sure how her previous save in the same browser window would cause an editing conflict. The same student reports receiving this message after trying to view their group wiki: Fatal error: Maximum execution time of 30 seconds exceeded in /content/webm/moodle/mod/wiki/ewiki/plugins/moodle/f_fixhtml.php on line 61 Fatal error: Maximum execution time of 30 seconds exceeded in /content/webm/moodle/mod/wiki/ewiki/plugins/moodle/f_fixhtml.php on line 71

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki as a controlled collaborative tool
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, in our ourganization it has been requested to set up an activity like wiki. however the constraint is that students should be able to modify the article, but only the teacher should be able to publish it. I do understand this is not the spirit of WIKI, however I wonder if it could be used to achieve such feature and if not, which other tool could be used to achieve mentioned mechanism. To recap: a student edits an article and "submit it for review" Teacher reviews article and approves it then publishes it. new student or the same one provides a modification of the same article and submits his version of the article for review. Teacher reviews modified article and approves it therefore publishes it. etc...

Please speak you mind and give us feedback there... we need your support because every day is more and more difficult to get into Moodle. Thanks Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Using a Wiki for Reading Summaries
ResponsesInList.Text: I would like to teach my students how to maintain a Reading Wiki where they can keep notes on their reading. I have created the Wiki, but for each article read I would like the student to have a Summary page, a Inquiries page and a Contributors page. I am relatively unfamiliar with the terminology used in wikis so I do not know if I need to create the article name as a category and then create the Summary, Inquiries, and Contributors pages as sub-categories (pages). I had tried simply using the brackets; however, then other articles link to that page. I would appreciate any advice on how to accomplish what I am trying to do with the wikis which could be outlined as: Class Reading Wiki Article #1 Summary Inquiries Contributors Article #2 Summary Inquiries Contributors Article #3 etc, etc. The reason I want the inquiries on separate pages is that I want the students to be able to edit at the same time. In other words a student could be working on the summary page while another is simultaneously working on the inquiries. If this could be accomplished by keeping it all on one page (as it appears in Moodle Docs - which I realize is a different type of wiki) that would be fine. Thanks again for any advise as I try to incorporate this in to my class. Peace.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using a Wiki for Reading Summaries
ResponsesInList.Text: I remain hopeful that some wiki expert will be able to help me figure out how to have repetitive subpage names in a wiki. I have read the documentation in MoodleDocs to no avail. The closest thing I found was a category but I am not able to get that working. I want my students to do reading summaries and come up with questions based on the reading. I want a summary and questions subpage for each article. I understand how to create a page; however, when they create a [Questions] link on the Article 2 page it takes them to the already completed [Questions] page for Article 1. I would greatly appreciate any guidance in wrapping my mind around this wild wiki world. Peace.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using a Wiki for Reading Summaries
ResponsesInList.Text: Anthony, I am by no means an 'expert', but my solution would be to create all the required pages with individual names and then to hyperlink to the appropriate page using the menu structure that you suggest. You can even hide the original wiki that you created to create all the different pages and then create a new wiki with the hyperlinks on it, so that you dont get the legacy wiki page links. Does that make sense? It might be a bit of a fudge, but it works!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using a Wiki for Reading Summaries
ResponsesInList.Text: Nigel - Thanks for your response. I am not sure that I completely understand.  I think you are suggesting that the pages be created using names like Article1Summary, Article2Summary, etc. to prevent the linking from taking the student to the same place; however, I want it to be displayed simply as summary. My attempts at using [Article1Summary | Summary] have not worked since even after the page is created I see the wiki new page question mark. When I click on it, then it takes me to the page but it is clear to me that something is not working. I am wondering if on a page, could I have sections ? Where students could modify one section at a time. I want the student doing the summary and the student doing the questions to be able to be writing and working at the same time without interfering with one another. Unfortunately, I do not understand that a legacy wiki page link is but I would happily accept the fudge.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using a Wiki for Reading Summaries
ResponsesInList.Text: Anthony, Ludo is the wiki guru. I bet he should be able to provide guidance on this. Juvenal

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using a Wiki for Reading Summaries
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank Juvenal - I am hoping that Ludo (or someone with experience using wikis in a similar way) might respond. Peace.

ResponsesInList.Text: When I started to work with wikis I intended to use it for my students to write documentation for projects, and I had a similar problem. Any documenta has the same parts, and we can't have two pages named "Introduction". Mediawiki being a single wiki does not solve this issue. Moodle wikis (all of them, just by being in Moodle architecture) offer us some solutions:

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using a Wiki for Reading Summaries
ResponsesInList.Text: Ludo - thanks for the reply and congrats on the recent releases. A) I am using groups which does manage setting up a wiki for each section. This aspect is working very well. B) In order to preserve the richness of wiki style interaction, I want all of the articles to be in a single wiki activity. C) I will have to check out nwiki and see if that might not be the best solution since the likelihood of having students simultaneously edit the same page can be reduced. I was trying to avoid some user frustration of being told that someone else had edited the page since them. But I do like the idea of being able to provide a style guide or template. D) Since I am working with high school students in the U.S., disciplined though they may be, it is probably best not to rely too much on a naming convention although that may be my best long term solution. Thanks for your assistance in helping me to process through the best way to implement wiki use in this situation. Peace.

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki login misbehaving
ResponsesInList.Text: I am experiencing problems when users attempt to login to edit a wiki page.  The scenario is as follows: Users visit the wiki page with guest login access. The page instructs them to use login link in footer to edit page. They login and are returned to the page, but login status is still set to guest and the wiki page doesn't display edit tab. They navigate to other pages of the wiki or anywhere on the site and login status shows that they are logged in. They navigate to the page they want to edit through the wiki site map and login status shows they are logged in. This doesn't occur on the users first visit to the page but on all subsequent visits to the site. Refresh (F5) of the page does not change login status In addition, the opposite effect occurs if the user logs out and revisits the page without closing the browser: User visits the page logged in Logs out Navigates to the page with guest login access When the page is displayed, user login status is logged in to their account User had edit tabs for the page Navigating to the page through the wiki sitemap results in guest login status & no edit tabs A sample wiki page that is having this problem is http://www.wels.net/university/moodle/mod/wiki/view.php?id=469 or http://www.wels.net/university/moodle/mod/wiki/view.php?id=469&page=group (link from sitemap) I have observed this behavior using both IE & Firefox browsers. I have searched the forums and not found mention of this behavior elsewhere, so please post links if it has been addressed already. Thanks! Sallie Draper

ResponsesInList.Title: All wiki images and files disappeared in Moodle 3.7.2
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear all, I set up a Moodle installation for my company. Except for courses, the main page features two wikis with multiple pages and multiple images per page. The wikis are collaborative as multiple users need to edit. All images and files (PDFs mostly) associated/embedded into wiki pages have suddenly disappeared. I can see the tags but if I copy/paste the link URLs in my browser, they seem to point to non-existing resources. I read in the forums this problem happens on various versions of Moodle but it is unclear to me if a solution or workaround to restore the wikis has been found. Could someone enlighten me about this particular issue? Thanks
role: Picture of Guido Antonio Di Carlo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: All wiki images and files disappeared in Moodle 3.7.2
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear all, I temporarily solved the issue by re-uploading all image files and attachments in the "Files" tab. Regardless of the user that originally uploaded the single files, all links inside wiki pages started working normally again. Strangely, though, the file uploader popped up an alert, asking me if I wanted to overwrite old files and images as if they were still present in the wiki.
role: Picture of Guido Antonio Di Carlo

ResponsesInList.Title: Private Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi I know wikis are usually collaborative but is is possible to create a wiki for each individual student in a course. I want them to have a place to document their own private goals. Their goals may change as they move through the course so I want them to be able to make changes to their wiki. Some of the goals may be sensitive so I want them to feel obligated to share with the group. Is it possible to set permissions for a wiki page which relates to the student log in? Hope this makes sense. Help appreciated. Ann

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Private Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Lets say it is a graduate group of only (say) 15 students. Create groups with one student in the group and assign wiki to groups. Lets say it is an undergraduate group of 200. Are you planning to read them all?? Probably this won't work. Is a wiki overkill? Here is another option: You could use an online text assignment, CALL it a journal, which is editiable on one page an unlimited number of times. It really functions like a one editor, one page wiki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Private Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks - I'll go the text assignment. Cheers! Ann

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Private Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ann The Online Text assignment would work well with this, If used it successfully in the past. You should warn your students to be careful that they don't accidentally remove existing text with each successive edit. I always recommended that students keep a backup in a Word document just in case! An alternative is the Dialogue module with allows private Teacher to Student communication however students can just keep adding entries, which are all date/time stamped. I hope this helps Cheers Teresa

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Private Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for your help and advice! I don't seem to have Dialogue as an option in my activities list. Is this something I need to download ? Ann

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Private Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ann Yes it is a Contributed module available on the Modules & Plugins database for download. Cheers Teresa

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Private Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: the OU wiki does exactly what you want to do. Best Fritz

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Private Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for your response. Ann

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Private Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ann thestandard Moodle wiki activity does exactly what you describe if you set the wiki type to 'student'. Then each student gets his/her own wiki. ralf

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Private Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Many thanks for your response. Ann
